It is this lucidity that you miss terribly, Madame von der Leyen. These crises that you do not see, however, affect the lives of hundreds of millions of women and men who, if they have not elected you, have the right to expect concrete answers from you. In the face of them, uncertainty, Mrs von der Leyen, is the privilege of the leaders because it is a matter of concern that the daily lives of citizens are made. They don't expect empty slogans and can't take any more of your contradictions. Today, you are announcing with great fanfare a new target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030; but it is already well below the 65% scientifically needed to comply with the Paris Agreement. How dare you further weaken this objective by a sleight of hand, by deducting emissions absorbed by carbon sinks, such as forests? This choice is irresponsible, Mrs von der Leyen. To save humanity from global warming, we need to reduce our emissions, not hack the books. You promise industrial sovereignty, but you continue to negotiate free trade agreements with Mexico, China, Mercosur and so many others. You claim to be reviewing the budgetary control mechanism, but you are about to demand that the recipient states of the stimulus package implement yet another austere reforms that no one wants. You borrow the word resilience and talk about new indicators of progress, but your policy is still looking for growth at all costs.  No one is fooled, Madame von der Leyen. If your words change gradually, your recipes remain the same: free trade, austerity and competition, the same recipes that have brought us to the brink. To cope with the urgency of the moment, we must change everything: our only compass must be the ecological and social bifurcation. It must be based on public planning and the massive creation of sustainable jobs in transport, freight, building insulation and energy transition. It must be financed by the restoration of fiscal justice, the taxation of crisis profiteers, the taxation of the greatest fortunes and the end of European tax havens. Mrs von der Leyen, you spoke for more than an hour and twenty minutes during that speech. At no time did you mention tax justice, the taxation of the richest, tax havens in the European Union, which are now plagued by the social justice of this Union. Finally, this bifurcation cannot take place without a contribution from the European Central Bank, at a minimum by cancelling the public debts it holds. It must start now, as part of an ambitious recovery plan in which every euro of public money is conditional on social and ecological counterparties for jobs and climate. That's enough, the blank cheques given to large companies that pollute and lay off to satisfy their shareholders ever more greedy for profits. Once again, let's be clear." This bifurcation will not be done by magic, crossing your fingers so that the invisible hand of the market naturally repairs what it has destroyed.  So, Mrs von der Leyen, if you want to get out of the uncertainty, finally agree to shake up your Certainties.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at one of the most difficult times for the economy, health and employment, the European Union has reacted with a recovery plan that provides for substantial funds against unemployment and for the environmental and technological transition.  Mr von der Leyen, the times are now the enemy of this recovery. We must move forward quickly and ensure that this recovery is an opportunity for everyone and not just for the few. As the 5 Star Movement, we expect the new European Green Deal to involve investments only in renewable energy without giving favors to fossil fuel lobbies. Well, then, the proposal announced on the minimum wage in all the Member States of the European Union, a proposal that the Movement has already made for some time in Italy; on own resources – therefore, digital tax, carbon tax, financial transactions – does not give way: we cannot increase the contribution of the Member States, which have already been put in difficulty by the pandemic, and demand further sacrifices from the citizens.  Finally, on the management of migratory flows, we need a mechanism that is automatic and compulsory and that provides for a fair distribution of responsibilities among all the Member States. On work, on the environment, on health, on economic recovery, citizens want action and we are here for them.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, listening to the Extreme Right shows again that there is a fundamental difference when looking at the human being and the individual.  We are convinced that each human being has a solemn dignity that can never be touched, independent of where this individual comes from. Obviously, the Extreme Right has a different view, that there are different types of human beings – 'them and us', and 'they' have to be confronted with hate. But hate has never given any good advice. So we will always insist on the fact that ... (In response to dissent from the floor) ... This makes him angry because we got him on the point where he sees that we have a different soul where that is concerned.  (Loud applause) And that's democracy. That is democracy. He has to bear it. He cannot bear the contradiction that they are preaching hate and we want solutions. We want a constructive approach towards migration because it will always be with us.  (Applause) Therefore this is the right moment for a fresh start on migration. Just two numbers: every year, about two million people come to Europe – two million – and 140,000 refugees. So we should be able to manage that. Two million people are coming to Europe. There's a good reason why. It's because Europe is a wonderful continent that offers a lot of opportunities. This is the normality, and on top of that 140,000 refugees last year. We should be able, we have to be able, to manage that. Therefore, we will put forward the legislation next week. There will be time to discuss it.  The rule of law. With the new report we will put forward before the end of the month, the Commission is taking the most systematic and the most comprehensive approach to the rule of law in our history. Because never before have we looked in such detail at these issues across every country. The report is not just on the judiciary, which is important, but also on anti-corruption, the media landscape, and institutional checks and balances. The report that will be published before the end of this month will show many challenges and then we will have a broad debate here, to really confront that. If it's necessary and we do need new instruments, new tools, well let's address it. This is what we're here for. That's why we do politics here. So that's a chance to move forward on that subject.  You mentioned the NextGenerationEU and the issue of jobs and that every euro can only be spent once – and that is right. And rightly so the demand to make more progress in the digital world. That's why NextGenerationEU will invest 20 percent in the digital – and that's right. We now have a plan, we have clear goals for 2030, we have clear tasks in infrastructure – in terms of data, in technology, we have laws that we want to get in place. This is the time when we need to proclaim the digital, the digital decade for Europe, and get it going! And it was rightly the idea that, in the huge investments we have with NextGenerationEU, we must live up to our responsibilities, that we make these investments precisely, forward-looking and efficient. And, ladies and gentlemen, I have also listened to you. I do not share the gloomy view of the world that you have, but rather I am one of those people who work with hope and who approach tasks with optimism. Ladies and gentlemen, these are, of course, difficult times. But what, in all difficult times, has mostly been the problem that has prevented us from moving forward? Firstly, the inertia of getting out of the current situation and, secondly, the lack of resources. That is different now! We do not want to stay in these Corona times, as we have them now! Nobody wants to stay at this stage. In other words, our own inertia is lifted, and we all know we have to move towards a world of Corona. And now the question is: How do we imagine the world after Corona? I have set out my vision of the world after Corona, and I believe that many in this House share it. And I believe that we have a responsibility – now with the deep conviction that people know that we need to move forward – to show European leadership, to develop European visions that will also show the world of tomorrow, and we have the investment. And to use these investments in a trustworthy, efficient, forward-looking way – that will be our common task. Many different opinions have become visible here – that is the beauty of democracy. Let's argue about it with each other! But I also felt a great broad majority in favour of a common conviction to bring this world forward into a greener world, a cleaner world, a healthier world with a powerful economy capable of to lead the way to the future with the modern technologies we need so that this planet can survive. We want to shape the future together. We do not see the downfall, but rather the progress, the opportunities that open up for us – and let us work on it together!

name: Laura FERRARA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In a crisis-ridden world, where nationalism and populism are showing their ugly face, where democracy is under pressure and authoritarianism is growing, it is about nothing more and nothing less than Europe's self-assertion. Today, Madam President of the Commission, you have given an optimistic view of confidence in Europe, and you have our support in this.  Madam President, you will certainly not have expected the Council to share each of your proposals in full. But it is important that, in these difficult times of crisis, we show a clear signal of cohesion and unity. And, of course, that includes the dispute, and we are prepared to do so. Every institution – the Commission, Parliament, the Council – bears its responsibilities, but in the end it must be clear that we are going in one direction, that we can agree on the essential principles.  Madam President, I assure you that, in the rapid conclusion of the largest financial package in the history of a united Europe, we will give you all the support you support in this regard. For we stand by the people who have suffered so massively from this crisis and are still suffering. Aid must arrive where it is most needed, and immediately.  However, Madam President, and here too you have our support, it is not just a question of investing in the old-fashioned. It is about further development, it is about rebuilding Europe, it is about a socio-ecological transformation of Europe. That's why you have our support in strengthening digitalization and climate protection. Climate protection in particular makes it clear that there are still great fears and concerns in our societies. That is why we need socially just climate protection. That is why you have our support here too, Madam President.  Social cohesion in a united Europe must be strengthened. The German Presidency will support you in making decisive progress on the EU-wide framework for poverty-proof minimum wages. For the phrase that nationalists and populists keep trying to convince us that climate protection is a job killer is not true. Climate protection secures future-oriented jobs. But it must be fair climate protection, and you have our support for this too. As you have said, Madam President, the European Union is not primarily an internal market. First and foremost, we are a community of values and a community of law. And this community of law and a community of values applies to everyone. And here we support you in building a stronger legal and value community. We support the introduction of the rule of law conditionality. We support you in establishing a rule of law mechanism, building on the report that we are already looking forward to and which we are eagerly awaiting at the end of September.  You have our support, Madam President, for us to speak with one voice in this crisis-ridden world. You have addressed the major global players – Russia, China, others. The most effective remedy against the poison of division is cohesion. The fact that we are always able to bring about a synthesis between different positions is difficult in the Council, which is difficult in all the institutions, but we are prepared to do so.  And, Madam President, you also have our support in building a migration and asylum policy that is committed to shared responsibility, solidarity and humanity, because migration and flight is not a national test alone, but a global and a European test. Europe is the place where we can all be different without fear. Religion does not count here, it does not count where you come from, who you believe in. There is only one thing that counts here: that we are committed to these values that Europe stands for. And that is the only way in which Europe, our Europe, will survive, and we will support you in doing so, as far as we can.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We are in crisis mode. COVID-19 is far from over, the virus continues to determine our daily lives, our lives, our economy. Many of our citizens are unsettled and our economy is under enormous pressure. I think that in times of crisis such as these, it is important – as you mentioned – to build trust and, above all, to set the right priorities. Priority 1 for me is the health of our citizens, and I must compliment the European Commission on this: mobilising EUR 16 billion to develop the vaccine, Madam President, I think that is great, as is your efforts to ensure that the vaccine, if it is then developed, is also made available to our citizens in Europe. Priority 2 must, in my view, be our economy. We have to guide our businesses through the crisis, our businesses are the jobs, our social systems are attached to our farms, our prosperity hangs. The figures I take with me from my home region, which are reflected throughout Europe, are, in my view, alarming. Jobs are being cut without end. In my region MAN 10 000 jobs, Schaeffler, Continental, ... Airbus is cancelling, the airports are largely paralyzed, the exhibition halls are empty, creatives have no work. We're really in the middle of it, and everything's on the run, and I realize it's just the tip of the iceberg.  I believe that Europe has made a powerful contribution to the reconstruction plan, but for me it is now important that we hold back on further regulation and further burdens, especially for our businesses, especially for our small and medium-sized family farms.  I share ambitious climate protection targets, but the details of implementation are important, and I would like to encourage you, Madam President, and the whole Commission, to put in place the mechanisms in the implementation of the Green Deal, the climate protection programme, which will make us successful in Europe.  Rely on market-based instruments, on the expansion of emissions trading, on technology neutrality. Electrification alone cannot be the solution, and above all, take our small and medium-sized enterprises with you. COVID-19 is a crisis, and I believe that we must now adapt our policy to this great crisis mode in the situation.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – F'dan iż-żmien ta' kriżi minħabba din il-pandemija, ir-rwol tagħna huwa li nibnu mill-ġdid l-ekonomiji tagħna biex ikunu reżiljenti u jkunu preparati għall-futur. Għalhekk huwa pożittiv li dalgħodu smajtek issemmi l-prijorità flower-aġenda diġitali u dik ambjentali. Hija urġenti llum, aktar minn qatt qabel. Jekk verament irridu nilħqu l-miri tagħna ta' carbon neutrality sas-sena 2050, irridu nibdew naġixxu mil-lum. Għalija huwa pożittiv li l-Kummissjoni Ewropea ppreżentat il-pjan tagħha biex sas-sena 2030 innaqqsu t-tniġis b'minn tal-inqas 55 %. Nafu li x-xjenza titlobna ħafna aktar minn hedge. Għalhekk li dan il-grupp politiku huwa kommess li jara li ma jiddaħħlux loopholes biex innaqqsu u ndgħajfu dik il-mira.  It-tieni punt huwa dwar il-qasam tas-saħħa. Irridu na大大ertaw ruħna li jkollna aktar kompetenzi fejn jidħol il-qasam tas-saħħa. Għalhekk li ser naraw li ma jkunx hemm tnaqqis fuq program daqshekk vitali u importanti. U l-aħħar punt: l-immigrazzjoni.  Nistenna li fiż-żmien li ġej naraw sin dwar l-immigrazzjoni ħafna iktar b'saħħtu. Irridu soluzzjonijiet innovattivi. Is-soluzzjonijiet tal-bieraħ, la huma qed jaħdmu llum, u lanqas mhu se jaħdmu għada. U jekk verament irridu li s-solidarjetà ma tibqax paroli fuq il-karta imma ssir fatti, irridu naraw li verament ikollna l-miżuri u l-għodda biex nindirizzaw din l-isfida.

name: Malik AZMANI
text: – Mr President, I would say to the President of the Commission that I think we can all agree it has been a turbulent first year for this Commission, and for us all. Madam President, you and your team started this mandate with high ambitions. But then the world was faced with perhaps the biggest health crisis in our history. As COVID—19 began to spread in Europe, everything came to a halt. Now that we have overcome the first shockwave of this pandemic, we have to pick up our momentum again. Not just to overcome this health crisis and protecting and creating jobs, but also by moving forward on other priorities. Take for example the awful scenes in Camp Moria last week, to which we have been referring. This is not the moment to look away, to kick the can that is called ‘migration policy’ down the road once more. This is the moment we have to decide. What is happening on Lesbos is unacceptable and we have a European responsibility to put in place a sustainable migration policy, so that we can avoid unnecessary suffering and so that we can regain control of migration. I am glad to see the Commission will present proposals next week. Last year you said in this House: our greatest achievements have always come when we are bold. And my question will be: will you be bold now? Secondly, the rule of law. How can we lecture other nations on respect for the rule of law, when the rule of law is no longer respected in part of our Union? ‘Rule of law can never be compromised.’ These are your words, and I share them. What will you do to ensure the EU remains a credible ambassador for rule of law in the world? Will you stand with us on having a rule of law conditionality in our new budget? We have an obligation to our voters, to our citizens of the EU, to deal with these and other challenges: the green transition; but also the digital transition – they are equal to me, they go hand in hand – and our foreign policy response that needs to be stronger and bolder in order for the EU to become the geopolitical actor you yourself spoke of last year. We have to show courage to focus on these priorities and set the wheels in motion. Madam President of the Commission, this year is going to be a real test case for you and your team. I ask you: are you up for it? Ready? With ‘Renewed’ energy?

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs von der Leyen, although I was very sorry that she took it up with the only real opposition in this Parliament. I was very sorry not to hear self-criticism of the mistakes made on economic and trade policies by the European Commission in recent years, and I was very sorry to see a mismatch with the propaganda that the Italian Government is currently making on the Recovery Fund, an Italian Government that will not be able to do everything it is promising its citizens.  I believe that, in the light of all this, it can be said that you are underestimating the crisis that we are experiencing and that we will be experiencing in the coming months, that you are underestimating what the United States is telling us about China. It is resounding that, for example, you have not mentioned on the international geopolitical stage the agreements that Israel, thanks to the incoming administration, is making with certain Arab countries and it is resounding that, as with China and Turkey, the courage, unfortunately, is still lacking. You see, my family comes from the fight against fascism, so I'm not afraid of his threats. When in 1943 my grandfather dropped the statue of Mussolini from the headquarters of the Municipality of Santo Stefano d'Aveto, let it appear, if he knew what he could meet! But I also reply to Mr Weber, who quoted the leader of my party: yes, Matteo Salvini, a true Italian patriot. He is an Italian patriot who has defended europe's borders and who will go before a court in Catania on 3 October.  If this is your idea of democracy, I prefer to suffer your attacks and rest assured that you will always find the answers from me and especially from the citizens behind us.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, we have been through difficult times this year and still difficult times lie ahead of us. So many challenges overlapping. You mentioned them. That’s why it is so important that this time the EU, contrary to the 2008 crisis, stands by its citizens, that the EU shows it is useful for fighting against a pandemic, for helping the economies recover, for taking care of people and businesses most affected by the crisis and useful for transforming these economies into greener and fairer ones.  But the EU also has to deliver when conflicts on democracy and self-determination arise inside the Union. Madame President, it’s not me who should be addressing you right now. It should be Oriol Junqueras, elected MEP and one of the Catalan political prisoners, shamefully behind bars for now almost three years. Yes, here Europe must deliver too, because this injustice is a stain not only for Spain but for the whole of Europe. So help them and the exiles be back home and demand that the Spanish government, once and for all, be brave and negotiate a solution for Catalonia based on respect and real democracy.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We have now listened to the speech, the speech by the President of the Commission. For me, it was strikingly similar to that of an extreme left-wing representative, who clearly shows that 'it is our views that are the right ones. Should you dare to have different opinions, then you should be branded as hateful and extreme" It is then that I ask myself, as a Swedish citizen, who is standing here today: why should we be involved in paying for this? Why should Sweden borrow money to give that money away to other EU countries without getting anything back? It is a truth with modification, because we get the debts that we hand over to our children and grandchildren whom they have to pay for many years. We have major problems in Sweden with constant shootings and bombings, just as in other countries, Germany, for example. I think we all remember Chancellor Merkel's speech Wir schaffen das!. No, you didn't! You have at least as much problems as Sweden has, and the longer you persevere in the construction of the United States of Europe, the faster there will be more referendums on leaving the EU.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Mr President! Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, the planet has a fever, the ice is melting, forests are burning. Climate action is urgently needed and urgent action is needed if we are to prevent the crisis from getting completely out of control. We know from science that the 55% reduction by 2030 is not enough, we need at least a 65% reduction if we are to live up to the Paris Agreement. If we do not do what is necessary, disaster will hit us hard. President of the Commission, listen to young people, listen to the climate movement, listen to science and take the necessary action on climate change now.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Mr President, the greatest economic crisis of our time has been knocking on our doors. Tens of millions of people are being threatened by poverty, hunger and civil unrest. It’s high time we do something. You have left over 100 million people, after the last crisis in 2008, in poverty. How many do you intend to leave in poverty after this crisis? I am hereby inviting you all to implement a universal basic income in all of Europe. I am ready to do whatever it takes to prevent my fellow Croatians and other nations of the European Union from going bankrupt. If we fail at this, if we don’t make this step, then Europeans will be on the breadline, stripped of everything. I am asking for no charity, I am asking to give people back what was taken from them by unjust crisis, by artificial crisis, and by bad policies. Many lives have already been ruined. Let us not ruin the lives of our children. Let us take this historic responsibility.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, President von der Leyen, thank you. Thank you for your ideas, your initiatives and your proposals. The proposals made by the European Commission over the course of last year and adopted by the European Parliament have saved lives in Europe, have helped care for people in need, treat people affected by the virus and helped overcome the crisis. Now is the time to start further strengthening the Union, further building the European Union, making it fitter for the future – a Union which is open, which is inclusive, which cares for those in need, and in which we can all strive; a Union in which we are all winning, in which people can strive, in which enterprises can innovate, can develop, in which countries are helping each other.  To achieve this we need the right tools. The main tool in order to achieve our objectives is the budget of the European Union. The budget is the holy grail to fulfilling our commitments. Without an ambitious budget all our commitments on greening, digital, helping young people, helping farmers, better protecting our borders, remain only empty words. What shall we do? Now is the time to equip the European Union with own sources of revenue – own resources. Own resources mean a stronger, a more stable, a more solid European Union. We must put in place own resources as early as the year 2021 to help pay back for the costs of the crisis and to help deliver to the people what we have promised. Own resources means that we can finance the traditional priorities of the European Union and we can also finance new priorities of the European Union – we can invest in research, in innovation, we can help farmers, we can protect all of our borders. It means that we can deliver on what people are expecting from the European Union. Madam President, one year from now on we will all remember the hard times but we will be judged by our actions. This is why I kindly request that you stand with us, stand with the European Parliament, to equip the Union with an ambitious budget, with a strong budget so we can deliver what people are expecting from us.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, Madam President, we are at a crucial moment for the future of Europe. As you have told us, if we want it to remain an essential player on the international stage, we must give ourselves the means, today and tomorrow. If the recovery plan is a major step and seems to be moving in the direction of solidarity, it is cyclical. It must not hide the weakness or limitations of the future European budget. The Union needs a strong multi-year budget, which involves the financial means and to finance it, including the creation of several own resources and, first of all, the financial transaction tax. On the other hand, we must focus on this totem which is the rule of law, without which the European Union would not exist. Yes, we must collectively overcome this unprecedented crisis and seize this moment to make the Union the spearhead of a profound transformation of our societies towards greater well-being for all, socially and environmentally. Yes, there is a climate emergency. Yes, there is a social emergency and we collectively no longer have the right to make mistakes. That is why we demand not only clarity, but boldness, Madam President, from your Commission and your college, for boldness for all and especially for the poorest.

name: Stéphane SÉJOURNÉ
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, I first wanted to say to colleagues that we must not allow the division that the extreme right and the extreme left of this Chamber are trying to create on the fact that there will be the lucid, on their side, those who have seen things, and then the Eurobeats, those who see nothing, those who are for Europe , which bring together the Socialists up to the EPP. I think it's quite dangerous to do that reading. Moreover, lucidity was first of all to make proposals in this crisis. I have not heard much from the two far-left and far-right groups in this Chamber. It must still be remembered, in this debate which is important for the future of Europe. In fact, this crisis and this year will still have baffled and astonished us, both in the way they have unfolded, both because the health crisis has blocked all of our institutions, including our own functioning. Of course, border-building measures are measures that have also surprised us in the way this has happened. And then, Mrs von der Leyen, like this year, the Commission surprised and baffled us. Astonished, because I think that the pact you initiated with the Franco-German agreement is up to the task. I think the answers in your speech are also up to the task. But we must also see - and I will repeat the elements of lucidity - our fragilities, both institutional, organisational and in the way this crisis has unfolded. We have been elected for a year now and there are few pieces of legislation that have come out of the Commission today. So there was COVID-19, of course, but I do not know which national parliament would wait a year before a legislative programme came. There is therefore an urgent need today and I find in your speech a voluntarism for this future year, which I call for, to accelerate the reforms and accelerate the urgency that we have been carrying since the beginning of this mandate.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, I am angry. Not so much because here today with so much fire you have exhibited your hatred for people, human beings, which you have all called far-right for convenience. I am angry because I want to convey the words of millions of Europeans about the way things are going. If I add up the number of dogmas that you have produced here today, I can speak of a religious speech, a religious speech in the Cathedral of Democracy, with a lot of bombast, but still a scandal. A scandal because you have made that European Union platform, which should be a form of free cooperation of free nations, more than ever a totally integrated, immigration-fuelled unitary state. That's why I'm conveying that anger. We're angry. Despite EUR 88 billion less contributions from the United Kingdom, you have increased that multi-annual financial framework and, together with the Corona Fund, you have in fact doubled the resources and therefore the political projects of this European Union. That is unacceptable. You are making the European continent something that we did not want.

name: Petra DE SUTTER
text: – Mr President, Covid—19 is still omnipresent in our daily lives, but also in the political debates. In the EU, we tend to focus a lot on economic recovery, but we must not forget that the health of every European citizen is even more important. European citizens worry about the future, about their health, about their jobs, about the climate, and about their future. This is the moment when we as Europe have to show that we are ready to help them, and that we’re on their side, step by step. How will we reassure people that there will be an affordable vaccine for all of us who need it? How will we convince people that we will coordinate Member States’ policies better during the next health crisis? The only way to show people we mean it is to maintain budgets that we set aside for EU for Health and Horizon Europe. These flagship programmes are crucial for the next generation of Europe and we will fight for them.  But the most important call that I want to strengthen is of course to redirect investments towards a green economy. Innovative companies are showing the way forward to a more circular economy and sustainable product design, as well as a socially just transition. Let’s keep our targets sufficiently high. Let’s listen to what the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) decided last week. We need at least 60% or 65% to be ambitious. The more we reduce now, the more relaxed we will be towards 2050.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, Mrs van der Leyen gave a speech of Castro-like size, I must say, but it was told in fairy-tale form. When I hear all these plans, as a Calvinist, I always ask myself, who's going to pay for that? Hello? Who's going to pay for that? Well, that's paid for through European taxes, so the citizen. And you come up with new European taxes. Fortunately, there are still the Member States, because they have to approve these taxes, that is, in national parliaments and in the Netherlands in the First and Second Chambers.  And then I ask myself: what is the position of the VVD and the CDA? Mr Azmani has just spoken. I haven't heard from him about how he's going to pay for it. He applauds it and then says nothing. Mrs. De Lange, what about your party? I don't know what blood type to ask, but where do you actually stand? And I would urge you to stop saying one thing in the Netherlands and vote for the other in Brussels. Say what you do and do as you say. It's just advice.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, you have spoken to us about the importance of investment in health, the promotion of collective bargaining, the defence of minimum wages in Europe, but it was your European Commission that five months ago was telling the Portuguese Government to cut health spending. It was the European Commission, several European Commissions, that promoted and pressured member states to dismantle collective bargaining systems. Several European Commissions have told mine and other governments to freeze the minimum wage and therefore what do we stand by?  What we will have in the coming years is a European Commission that will signal an absolute turning point in European policies in these areas, or are these just beautiful ideas to put in your speech, while your technical teams press governments to do otherwise? On the environment, I would like to understand one thing: how have we radically changed the targets for reducing carbon emissions - and it has not been enough - without presenting the concrete measures that will support these more ambitious goals, because what it seems to be listening to is that there is simply unwavering faith in industry leaders , which brought us here, in new technologies whose results are uncertain, to be sympathetic, or in the old technology of hammering the bills, which may deceive some citizens, but does not deceive the planet.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Mr President, the failure of commercialised public health systems in all the countries of the European Union to deal with COVID-19, of the tens of millions of workers who have lost their jobs or are currently suspended, of the 95 million people living below the poverty line, it turns out that your policy is unpopular and has as its criterion the profits of the few. In the face of the new capitalist crisis, what you are interested in is strengthening European groups against their competitors with the sweat of workers. That is why you are idly putting new taxes on peoples who misleadingly call themselves own resources, while the recovery plan is mainly directed at supporting businesses in highly profitable areas such as green energy, digital technology and networks. The peoples of Europe have paid too much for both your development and judgment. They will not accept to reload new burdens and memoranda with national recovery plans. They will fight for their modern rights against the strategy of the European Union, governments and monopolies that you represent.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The day-to-day life of the Union is burdened by serious internal divisions rather than the mutual trust hoped for. These divisions shackle the lives of hundreds of millions of European citizens. As a result, the Union has lost its leading role in the world. If we do not face this fundamental problem, the serious internal divisions, then all our plans will remain a wish. I therefore wish to formulate three proposals to end the divisions that have weakened the Union. Above all, the political and ideological Cold War against the Member States and the application of double standards must end. It is shameful when eu institutions and politicians attack the Member State that successfully defends against the coronavirus epidemic and protects people's lives and health on the basis of junk lies. Secondly, the European Commission should make proposals to end institutional divisions within the Union. Take the initiative so that citizens of all EU Member States can work freely and have the same access to free employment in other countries. The Commission should immediately propose to remove the competitive disadvantages that lead to divisions in legislation that discriminates against small and medium-sized enterprises in Central and Eastern Europe, such as transport and transport. And a decision should be taken immediately on the accession of Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania to Schengen. Despite their decades of EU membership, citizens of these countries are still excluded from the Schengen system. This state is a sad symbol of the Divisions of the Union. Thirdly, the European Commission should finally formulate new legislative proposals, in particular on climate protection, the so-called social pillar and immigration, which will not lead to new and even deeper divisions, further ideological debates, but which enjoy broad support from the Member States and the EU institutions.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Mr President, we like to speak about the Union’s value-driven soft power. We are proud to be a model, a positive force for the world and standing up for the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. But how long can we keep up that image if we fail to apply those standards to ourselves? How can we speak about protecting human rights when thousands of people, many who fled war, are now going through the most inhumane misery on the Greek islands? When we hear phrases being used like ‘protecting frontline countries and our borders’, I believe we have forgotten who the real victims are here. How can we speak about supporting the fight for democracy in Belarus when we do nothing when our own Member States are turning into autocracies?  The next EU budget must have an insurance policy against our own autocrats. President von der Leyen, we expect you to protect our citizens but also to protect our values.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Monsieur le Président, c'est dommage que M. Bay ne soit plus là, lui qui donne des leçons à tout le monde, même sur le financement du fonds de redressement, à un moment où c'est lui, M. Salvini, Mme Le Pen et leurs amis autrichiens qui reçoivent de l'argent de M. Poutine. Peut-être qu'il peut s'occuper de repayer l'argent à M. Poutine. Je trouve ça personnellement scandaleux que des gens pareils soient en train de nous donner des leçons, alors qu’ils reçoivent de l'argent pour détruire l'Union européenne. C'est peut-être ce qu’il est en train de faire, je suppose, parce qu'il n'est plus là.  My proposal, Ms von der Leyen, is that you repeat these 75 minutes of your speech, that I liked a lot, in the Council. Because let’s be honest, half of the issues that you raised are in fact blocked in the Council.  When we talk about migration, the tragedy in the Moria camp. That’s the consequence of the impossibility to reform Dublin, to reform the Migration Policy. When we talk about Belarus, it’s 40 days after these elections were stolen by Lukashenko and we are not capable of putting sanctions on the table – 40 days later.  When we’re talking about Turkey drilling in the Eastern Mediterranean, in Greek waters, no sanction, no action at all. When we talk about Hong Kong, when we talk about the minority of the Uighurs, words yes, but sanctions no, action no.  And when we talk about the rule of law inside the European Union, let’s be honest, it’s 5...6 years that we are talking about that here in Europe and in the European Parliament. There are no sanctions against these authoritarian regimes.  So my plea to you, is to repeat this as fast as possible, or in 75 minutes in the Council and let’s make a pact, a deal between us, that that is the priority for 2021 next to the Recovery Fund, Mr Frans Timmermans, and to the Green Deal, naturally. That is the priority. To end unanimity, to have a Magnitsky or Navalny Act as Mr Borrell named it. And to have a real rule of law mechanism, because I don’t want it to be that at the end, in a few years, we are calling you not the geopolitical Commission, but the geominimal Commission - that I want to avoid. (Applause)

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, Madam von der Leyen is wrong. The EU did not succeed; it broke the rules. No matter how much von der Leyen is trying to convince people that she’s better than us politicians critical of the EU, she broke the no-bail-out rule. We didn’t.  A community that does not follow its own rules has no credibility. The EU is a hypocrite. What Europe needs now is immediate tariffs on Chinese imports, following the example of the United States, to save its own industrial production and European way of life. We are the ones who want to follow the rule of law and von der Leyen does not. That needs to be made clear.

name: David CORMAND
text: Mr President, Madam President, dear friends, you said in your speech at one point: 'Fortunately we had digital technology during the crisis.' I thought, at that time, "Fortunately also we had a number of jobs", the so-called everyday jobs: nurses, garbage collectors, delivery men, those who were busy shopping. Indeed, they have been very helpful. As you said, for these people, work does not pay. On the other hand, for others, it pays. For others, the annuity pays, financial transactions pay, the destruction of the environment pays. In your speech, you talked about everything we had to do. There is one subject on which, in my opinion, we have not put enough emphasis: it is about revenue. I have a message for you: if we want an ambitious Europe, if we want to have the means to do our actions, those who today are exempt from tax must pay the tax. There is a tax that you did not mention, the financial transaction tax. We have been talking about this for years; it is a fair tax, which saves ordinary citizens who cannot escape tax. So, Madam President, as our friend Mr Verhofstadt has said, tell the Council that this House will not tolerate that there are no new own resources to finance everything we need to fund.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Mr President, resilience, sustainability, gender equality, digital Europe, Green Pact, Agenda 2030, more competences for the Union, more European laws, more European taxes, and now even a coordinator against racism: blah, blah, blah. With all due respect, Mrs Von der Leyen, ladies and gentlemen of the popular, liberal and socialist groups, what world do they live in? Did you guys go out there? Have you seen the 'closed' posters in business, even here next to the European Parliament? If you want, I'll walk you to Spain to see the queues to pick up food and clothes in the parishes. And this is going to get worse. And it's going to get worse if you don't touch reality and forget about your global agendas, full of "climate," "immigrationism," progressiveism and socialism. Brussels, if it doesn't touch reality, it will sink the whole of Europe.  It's time to bring back our industry; it is our turn to defend our families and workers; it is up to us to bet on law and order, to ensure security at our borders; finally, for this Europe of homelands and voluntary collaboration. Mrs Von der Leyen, you have finished your speech with a 'Long live Europe'. If I may, I will end mine with a 'Live the European nations, live the Europeans and live Europe!'.

name: Chris MACMANUS
text: – Mr President, in 2016, Sinn Féin MEPs warned this Parliament about the threat Brexit was to the Good Friday Agreement. Little did I realise that, four years later, I would be saying the same thing.  We have a long experience with the British establishment. We know that they don’t care about Ireland, north or south. We know that they renege on their commitments. They have continually reinterpreted, misinterpreted and ignored the Good Friday Agreement to suit their own domestic political agenda. Now you are learning what we have known all along. They cannot be trusted. The British legislation is not only a breach of the Withdrawal Agreement, it is a full frontal assault on all aspects of our Good Friday Agreement. So, again, we look to you all in Europe to help protect our agreement, our peace process and to help us escape from British misrule.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, respected colleagues, respected President of the European Commission, today you stated that we as a Union do not seek to be a leader but to be there for help. That sounds to me like the world's best athlete lets others win every race.  The European Union has all the abilities to be a world leader in all areas and we have to strive for it and we have to achieve it.  You spoke of the rule of law, however, it is terrible that it is the European Commission that violates and does not comply with the Visa Regime Regulation. Seven years, therefore, a visa for Citizens of the United States is not introduced in the event of reciprocity, as the United States has a visa regime for the four members of the European Union. That's inadmissible!  We act like mice, and we're supposed to be like lions. And we must respect our regulations.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President, the coronavirus has placed the European Union in the face of the greatest challenge of our lives. The pandemic has caused unimaginable damage. Thousands of families have lost a loved one. Millions of people have lost their jobs. In these severe hours, the European Union, more than ever, must be at the side of those who need it most. No COVID sufferer can go uneded. The economy and employment must be recovered. Europe cannot afford a lost generation. We need the vaccine. It is essential and must be accessible to all. But we cannot rely exclusively on the exit from the health, economic and social crisis to the vaccine, because everything lost and destroyed so far will only be recovered if we take urgent action already.  The Recovery Plan is indispensable. For it to be effective and transform, we need national governments to do their homework. With an impetus for ambitious national reforms, which fosters a modern, resilient, competitive economy, in the face of climate change and the digital age, that prioritizes the creation of quality jobs, because it is the best social policy, that strengthens national systems and guarantees, above all, the best education for all our young people.  We must make Europe again a beacon of freedom that illuminates a world that is getting dark again. Because coronavirus has also accelerated phenomena that were already occurring and undermined the strength of the Union and the future of Europeans. We cannot take a step back in defending rights and freedoms. Not a step back in defending democracy in the face of authoritarian threat comes from Belarus, Venezuela or even within our own societies. Not a step back in defending the rule of law against these retrograde nationalisms and populismos. Let us get an orderly Brexit and regain among ourselves the spirit of Schengen. The new reality must not mean the renunciation of our European values.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Only last week, the EU-China Summit took place, and I believe that this summit has once again shown us how important it is that the European Union is prepared for the future and is also independent. I believe that when we talk about industrial policy, we must be clear about it – and that was the area in which you announced that you might not go into detail, but I would like to raise it again.  In these industries, I believe that there are two where we can be world leaders and where we can also set the standards, as you said: firstly, the European hydrogen industry and, secondly, the European battery cell industry.  I believe that we have two people, together with our two Commissioners, Mr Timmermans and Mr. Efsovic, who have already caused a stir around the world with concrete measures. What we still lack is precisely these specific legislations. I mean, to speak of a Chinese philosopher: demand much of yourself and expect little from others. If we follow this principle, we will continue to be successful in the future.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, today we are in the hurricane called COVID. Very soon we will be in the hurricane called Brexit. Both will test the European Union, our society, our economy and the faith of our citizens. This is why we need strong leadership now, a strong EU that helps citizens and keeps Europeans and European businesses safe – something that citizens have been waiting for since the spring.  The Commission does not need new powers to do it. Let’s exploit its existing ones. You must accelerate your actions and grant additional aid and exceptions to our industry. Now is really not the time to burden them with new regulations.  President von der Leyen, the EU economy is a ship in a hurricane and we need a captain to navigate us safely to shore. I hope you will be that captain.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Mr President! President von der Leyen, in your speech, you said that migration was an enrichment for Europe. You're wrong! Immigration from Africa and the Middle East has not been enrichment for Europe. Not in my home country of Denmark, nowhere else. On the other hand, this has led to rising crime and high costs. I believe that this Commission and previous Commissions are betraying their responsibilities for the European continent. But you're right about one thing, and that's that there's one of them and one of us. And there's one of them and one of us in this house in particular. There is an EU elite that has for years neglected to make our external borders secure, which has used its energies to fight our national border controls instead. And then there is a us who, whatever the price, will defend our countries, our continent and surrender it in a better position for the future than when we ourselves received it from previous generations.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Madam President, you said that you do not want to tolerate the breach of European law. But what is happening at the moment in Moria, at our external borders? In Moria, not only the refugee camp burned. European law and the European legal community have been burning at the external borders for years. It is on fire. With the current foreign policy on asylum and refugees, Europe is breaking its own law. And that is the same for Bulgaria: for months, people there have been demonstrating – without any reaction from the European Commission – against impunity and corruption. Many everyday products contain banned chemicals – against European law. Germany is a money laundering paradise – against European law. In the same way, we find numerous violations in the area of fundamental rights.  I therefore ask you for next year: be more consistent as guardian of the Treaties. Open infringement proceedings. The blockades of the member states – you can't do anything about that. But you can enforce European law and thereby strengthen respect for our legal community and for the European project.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, even with the pandemic, we must, more than ever, focus on sustainable prosperity, job creation, and I have heard good things in your speech: attention to industrial policy, to artificial intelligence and to digitisation, but please focus much more on deepening the internal market, creating a capital market for our small and medium-sized enterprises.  You would also do well to present the EU as the global actor in trade and stability. I fully agree with you on that front. But I would like to be a little more assertive when it comes to human rights. Surely we cannot continue to import products made in China with forced labour? Let us also be very consistent in this area. Let us also oppose dumping and excessive state subsidies.  Thirdly, much more budget to innovation, the key to recovery, the key equally for the Green Deal. It's good that hydrogen is on the radar, but remember that we will have to invest in replacements of rare materials. We're way too fragile there, so increase that budget for innovation. Finally, humane asylum policy, but it protects our external borders and does not allow illegal immigrants in. This is what people ask. This is what will create confidence in the Union.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Mr President, Madam President, your speech sets ambitious targets, but if we do not take the means to act, they will remain endless appeals. Europe's vulnerability to the health crisis should be a lesson for us. You have called for an ethic of new technologies and digital technology, but if we do not invest in our countries to regain their strategic autonomy, we will be the satellites of the technological powers of tomorrow. You mentioned the migration challenge. Of course, the tragedies that take place in the Mediterranean Sea should prevent us all from sleeping, but the only way to avoid them is to assume to control our borders, so that no one tries to enter Europe without having been legally allowed. It is on our powerlessness that the trafficking of human beings that causes so many deaths today thrives. You recalled the ecological emergency. Again, how naïve there would be to believe that we will deal with this global problem only by seeking to reform ourselves! Of course, we can and must produce better, but Europe emits 8% of carbon emissions. If we are simply imposing constraints on those who produce in Europe, we will not have made progress in the field of ecology; we will only have destroyed our economy. It is time to make the single market a lever to move towards this global ecological transition. That is why the carbon inclusion mechanism is absolutely urgent. Finally, you have called for hatred not to tear our societies apart, but it will only be possible to resist all that divides them today if Europe assumes what we have in common: a civilization that we must pass on. It is only on this condition that it will also find a future.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you to President von der Leyen for a very strong speech. Yes, we have all been affected by the crisis and the pandemic. We are therefore faced with strong leadership, and we are faced with the need to show action on the part of europe in building sustainable economic growth and creating new green jobs. We're not going to build the old economy. We're going to build the new, green economy. The single market, the digital economy, climate-neutral technologies – all of it will be crucial for the new jobs.  However, we shall also push for a more social and ecological Europe, where living and working conditions take place. In this work, we know from Sweden that the most successful model for wages is collective agreements. Last but not least, I would also like to highlight gender issues. President von der Leyen did not mention the gender equality strategy, but I do because it is good for both women and men and not least for children and young people who are to grow up in an equal and equal Europe.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Mr President, Mrs Von der Leyen, it has been a very difficult few months. Many citizens have lost their loved ones, run out of jobs, or had to close their business. But I think we should be proud of the response to this crisis in the European Union.  When we approve the EU Recovery Plan, we send a very important message to our fellow citizens: Europe is with you, Europe is not going to leave you alone, we are going to leave it together. But it's not all settled. Money has to be spent well; some governments want to spend it foolishly. The Vice-President of the Spanish Government, for example, this week, in an interview, suggested that Recovery Plan funds should be used to create new business elites. And I want to say this with absolute clarity: from this European Parliament, we will do what is necessary to ensure that money is spent well, not spent to help friends and friends; used to support families in education, health care; to fight climate change and protect our planet. Because Europe is not an ATM, but an opportunity to fight for the well-being of our families.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to focus on one of the biggest topics for the next year: the New Migration Pact. I’ve seen this idea that was proposed already, and I think the most remarked thing is that the Commission is going forward to push the idea of migration codes and of relocation for migrants. I don’t have to be very smart or clever to understand that it’s going to be like a huge conflict between the Member States. The problem is that several countries have pushed this idea, like German or Sweden, and have practised their open borders immigration policy. They have ignored the fact that absolutely different cultures and religions don’t fit together. It doesn’t work. And now they’re trying to export their problems to other Member States. Liebe Frau von der Leyen, lassen Sie also Deutschland oder Schweden in ihren Ländern so regieren, wie sie es möchten, aber machen Sie nicht andere Länder für deren fatale Fehler verantwortlich, und lösen Sie Ihre Migrationsprobleme allein.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank President von der Leyen for the State of the Union. I think it’s an ambitious programme and it is absolutely clear that this Commission wants to do things differently. There is a change of course; we hear that and we very much support that. We also think that it reflects the results of the elections last year, where European citizens were asking for that change, very well. So we thank you for that.  But, of course, now it comes down to action. The words need to be translated into action, and there is sometimes still a big battle ahead of us, a big battle that we also need to have here in the European Parliament. I want to direct these words to my colleagues, who quite often applaud the nice speeches of the Commission and the statements that are being made but which are not being translated into law-making that really makes that change. We are still supporting subsidies for fossil fuels, we are still not strong enough on the rule of law, and we are still not fighting to make sure that refugees are being helped on this continent. These issues now need to be taken care of. After the words, the real work has to start, and we are willing to do that together to make sure that this Europe becomes a green and a social Europe.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Mr President, Honourable Madam President, honourable, honourable Commissioners, dear colleagues. Madam President, I regret to report that your speech was disappointing, full of half-truths and contradictions.  You are talking about the rule of law, and you are about to break the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union by drawing on a huge loan that our children will have to pay to fund crazy social experiments. You're talking about a free market, and you're imposing force packs like Mobility that steal jobs from Central and Eastern Europe. You're talking about jobs, and you're about to close hundreds of thousands of jobs in Central and Eastern Europe.  You're talking about human rights, and you dare not say the name of the neo-Nazi dictator Erdogan and communist China. I wonder why you are afraid to ask communist China when it will take responsibility for the Chinese virus that has devastated the world economy. You talk about expanding the European Union, but you are not saying that a Macedonia should enter only when it burys and forgets forever its communist, anti-Bulgarian, Macedonian past. You don't want a flag with a five-pointed and sickle and a hammer in this room, do you? Or you do, I don't know. You also talk about illegal migration by calling them refugees. Dear Madam President, we are not talking about refugees, we are talking about hundreds of thousands, millions of illegal immigrants who will culturally change the identity of European nations, sovereign European nations. You blame the far-right, dear Madam President, but they rule the far right, you rule. Wake up, get out of this Brussels bubble, get out of this closed area where you live and look at life as it is. Thanks for the attention.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her work and for the time being Protect the climate, protect the environment, take people and businesses with them, approach a market economy with openness to technology. Climate protection is not only necessary for the planet, it is also an opportunity for the European economy, especially in the global markets.  That is why we are right to issue a warning from the President of the Commission – towards climate neutrality as soon as possible! We also support the 55% by 2030, but questions on the Commission proposal are still allowed: why does the impact assessment say that what was impossible before the Corona crisis is possible today? At the time, it was said that 40% was in line with Paris and that the burden on people and businesses was - now it is 55%!  However, we are only in the middle of the pandemic, Brexit is imminent, African swine fever, no one, not even Mr Timmermans, can seriously say today what distortions this is causing on world markets. We therefore need a review of the impact assessment and climate targets in two years at the latest, and almost more importantly: our small and medium-sized enterprises need freedom for innovation, i.e. no bans on technology or remediation quotas, but a market economy and emissions trading. We are talking today about the Climate Act, the Supply Supply Supply Act, new taxes and levies. Of course, all this is true, but I would like to ask the Commission: where is the voice of small and medium-sized enterprises in the Commission? Where is the promised contact for SMIs? Where is the one-in-one rule? We cannot always just subsidise and regulate, we must also allow room for manoeuvre for companies, especially in the crisis and especially on the issue of climate protection.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: – Dear Mr President, Dear Madam President, today the vast majority of Europeans feel uncertainty and anxiety about their future, their income, their work, their families. For your call for more optimism to be heard, action is needed. It is great that after the initial shock, including with the very active role of the Socialists, the European Union has taken important decisions on the economic recovery resulting from the pandemic. Most importantly, historically, of course, this is the issuance of a common European debt in order to provide resources for investment and for people and businesses to get real outstretched hand and support. But now vital is the speed at which this will be realised. Slashed budgets for the coming years are not the answer and the path to global leadership. Most of the policies needed to rebuild the European Union have been proposed by the Socialists for quite some time and they require implementation to make Europe more social, fairer, more democratic. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that for more than two months thousands of Bulgarian citizens have been protesting about these European values, which you are talking about, a accountable government, transparency, democracy. They expect their voice to be heard in the European Union and to have a reaction. I urge you to act in this way. Thank you.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Madam President von der Leyen for your very ambitious and pro-European speech this morning. I particularly welcomed your strong words on the importance of the rule of law. They are great words that meet with the approval of this House, as you know. Unfortunately, they also meet with the approval of the government offices in, say, Budapest, Warsaw and other places, and I think that, unfortunately, corrupt, autocratic leaders like Viktor Orbán and others listen to your speech knowing that they have nothing to worry about, because for years now they have been attacking democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights with impunity, and they have become an example to others. Others are following because the Commission is afraid to speak up to the Member States. It is a profoundly intergovernmental Commission.  In Poland, can the judges and the LGBTI people count on you to stand shoulder to shoulder with them as you stand shoulder to shoulder with the protesters in Belarus? Can the journalists in Bulgaria count on your support? Can the academics in Hungary count on your support? I thank you for your words, Madam President, but you will convince us only with actions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Perhaps allow me to say in advance that so much of the denial of reality and self-congratulation, as is manifested here in this House, is very, very rare. One almost gets the impression that a parallel universe has emerged here, which has nothing to do with the world outside.  If you had been half-honest today, you would have had to make a declaration of bankruptcy and surrender of your policy instead of consecting yourself. Look at the central areas of this European Union, where nothing works everywhere, whether that is the question of Corona, where you left Italy and other states completely in the rain at the beginning of the pandemic. Look at Moria: you have learned nothing from the migration crisis since 2015. You are still spreading your arms, bringing people from all over the world to Europe and ignoring the many problems that arise with it. Today, you postulate your climate policy magnificently. You close your eyes when trucks across the continent transport agricultural products without any sense, rather than relying on regionality. And on the other hand, you then take the money out of one pocket and put a fraction of the money in the other pocket. This is a hocus-pocus policy, but not an honest policy for the people.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. Self-knowledge is, it is said, the first way to improve. If you realise that your policies are on the wrong track, if you make a U-turn, if you make a proper policy, people will benefit, and your image will also benefit.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, it is time to help the people who have had the worst time in this crisis and who will do worse with the economic crisis. You have today made important announcements, such as the Minimum Wage Directive, or your climate ambition, with the 55% target in 2030, which we welcome. But I also have to tell you that, for climate ambition to be real, we need the Legislative Regulations to clearly exclude money from the recovery fund from being used to invest in fossil fuels or polluting energies. I hope the European Commission can help us in this.  Today Europe is on a more social and greener path. It's to celebrate. I also want to say that this is a victory of all those who for years fought against the "austeritarian" dogma — "by force hang," which some would say. But I have to tell you, Madam President, that you have finally left the great black hole of the European Union at the moment, which is our policy of immigration and asylum. Our defense of human rights, our rule of law die today in the moria countryside. And I know that it is not all your responsibility; we are well aware of it. But I ask you for greater political leadership to deal with the situation, the humanitarian emergency, and for the Member States to finally agree to relocate these refugees. Your political leadership is necessary on that issue more than ever, and I think that is also your responsibility today, and I have to regret that that part has left it for the end. I believe that the Commission must be much more forceful in the face of such a systematic violation of human rights as that which has occurred and occurs at our borders.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to President von der Leyen that sometimes speeches are inspiring but not credible. Other times they are credible but not inspiring. But this time it was both inspiring and credible. Thank you very much.   – Madam President, nevertheless I would like to raise a question: I have seen little reference to young people and, Madam President, young employment is in crisis. After a crisis in 2008 and 2009, now a crisis in 2020. This means that there is a generation that will be 20 years in crisis, first in 2008 and then to recover by 2020 and, when it was recovering, leads with another crisis. There is a generation of lost young people and they have to be a preferred target of European policies. Secondly, I would like you to be able to tell us what principles will inspire the Schengen reform, because i said that there is a new strategy for the future of Schengen and it is very precise, but what principles will inspire it? It is essential to respond to this, because we have demonstrated at the moment, for example, that many of the guards who were at the external borders are at the internal borders of the Union, desguarnecethe outer space and creating problems in the interior space and, finally, I also liked to have had a stronger and clearer word for the Conference on the Future of Europe. To say that it has to deal with the Health Union is undoubtedly important, but the Commission needs to be a driving force, or we will not have a Conference on the Future of Europe in the coming months to start and I think that will be a very big loss for Europeans at the moment, which is a turning point for Europe , as you have shown here.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr von der Leyen, thank you for this impassioned speech. The pandemic surprised us a little, in some respects, a few months ago, with a Union with health expertise still very limited in relation to health emergencies and with health systems still full of imbalances. This is why the global health summit, in 2021 in Italy, which you announced, is very good news. The right to health is a human right and we must make it a reality again: that is not always the case today. And on the subject of rights, only yesterday, before this Parliament, he spoke out against the very serious violence against LGBTIQ activists in Poland. I am pleased with his clear words on the rule of law, but we want consequent action: new anti-discrimination laws and sanctions against the Hungarian and Polish Governments. We need to move forward, Mr von der Leyen, with the reforms of the institutions; we need mechanisms against the Council's vetoes, we need to tax speculative finance and the major polluters to support the transformations of our society and the new common debt. Finally, we must support the new generations, who cannot bear the burden of this crisis on their own: much, much more needs to be done for them.  Together we can fight, together we can do the good of our citizens. We are ready: we want the Commission on our side.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, I would like to thank mrs von der Leyen for her work on this 429 – this is not the number of children who should be admitted from Moria first. But it is 429 days since you spoke for the first time in this House. 429 days of waiting for the European Commission to finally address one of the biggest issues where people expect a European solution.  In the course of your speech, I almost thought that you would not raise the issue at all, but then you would have a few key points on migration and asylum policy. You want humanity and solidarity, sea rescue – you have the full support of Renew. They want to improve the integration of recognised asylum seekers – full support. repatriation of those who are not entitled to asylum - agree. But what you have presented today lacks an important building block. Mrs von der Leyen, if there is no concept of how we organise migration into the labour market, which we need in some Member States, at European level, people will continue to set themselves in boats to cross the Mediterranean. There will continue to be overcrowded camps at the EU's external borders. And that is unacceptable.  If you want to organize migration holistically, then you have to think about migration into the labour market. As the Renew Group, we have put forward a proposal for a European talent pool with Canadian-style immigration criteria. Please take this up, do not stop halfway.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, we are both the first generation to suffer the effects of climate change, but also the last generation to be able to remedy it. There is no plan B for the planet. Look at the disaster scenario all over the world, from the Amazon to Greenland, from Australia to the Mediterranean. From now on, nature does not adapt to small steps, it reacts with great strides. Today, we must limit the damage, due to the inaction of successive governments. I would remind you that the first victims are the poor and the most insecure. Climate justice must therefore be addressed with social justice. Mrs von der Leyen, I ask you one thing: don't wait for the Green Revolution, do it. The reduction in emissions by 2030 is less than 65%, in line with COP 21. Get into the ecological transition, especially aviation and maritime. Relaunch the freight, Mrs. von der Leyen. The battle of the climate is the battle of jobs. We have a historic moment, an unprecedented moment in the history of mankind. The windows of opportunity are shrinking very quickly. So let's give ourselves the means to win the climate. Let us all work together to make Europe the climate leader. You said the countdown was on, but it's already here.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Mr. President, I would like President von der Leyen to know that one sentence in her speech made me particularly happy. Madam President, don't get me wrong, I congratulate you on your entire speech but, in particular, your promise to adjust our competition framework, especially given the international situation which often lacks fairness and a level playing field. Because let's be honest, if we want European companies to produce our green and digital goods and services, they at least deserve a fair chance. For this a revision of our competition and public procurement rules is, according to the PPE Group, long overdue.  – A fair opportunity for companies will ensure the preservation of jobs, jobs that would certainly be lost in the case of a nexit, as Mr Eppink wants. Or didn't he want a nexit? Explain it to me again. In any case, solve the schizophrenia in your own party and in your own head before pointing to others.  And where Mr Eppink performs a ritual dance, I have, as my constituents expect me to, dived into the proposals, and there I see on page 244 of the impact assessment in the Climate Act that, if an average family is reduced by 55% CO2 by 2030, I will save EUR 70 in heating costs, but will lose three to four times that amount to sustainable appliances and the insulation of their homes.  Madam President, this is about the people you spoke about, who, at the end of the month, have 'month' but no money left over and who are worried about their jobs. You can't be green if you're red. You also have these people in countries that do not benefit from the FFF or the mechanism for a just transition, so at the moment when we have an answer for these people as to how we are going to help them make that effort, I will be on your side, but I am still waiting for that answer.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Monsieur le Président, Madame la Présidente von der Leyen, merci pour ce grand discours. L'Europe in avait besoin. The pandemic and the health crisis have upset our lives and the agenda of our European project, but they are also offering us a historic opportunity to restore enthusiasm and hope to our citizens. Our political priorities at the beginning of this legislature have become political, social and economic emergencies.  The Union has survived all kinds of crises and has always been strengthened. And this time we will achieve this with a courageous and forceful response, based on adequate budgetary means and through new own resources. The foundations and principles of economic recovery have been laid in July and it must now be the Member States that present and carry out the reforms. Reforms that, as President Pedro Sánchez has proposed, must be developed by the regional and local authorities and aimed at strengthening public health, the right digital and ecological transition, as well as social and territorial cohesion and gender equality. In this regard, I would like to congratulate you, Madam President, on further strengthening parity in the College of Commissioners with the appointment of our colleague McGuinness.  Let us continue to make history and work together to improve the state of the Union and strengthen the confidence of citizens in the European project.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, I join my colleagues in thanking President von der Leyen for her commitment. Over the last year, our systems have been tested like little else before. We must now be able to respond faster to shared challenges and we must have common solutions and protocols that work first of all to preserve our single market under the Schengen area, to ensure joint procurement becomes the norm, to safeguard our environment and fight climate change, and to protect and create jobs and opportunities for a new generation looking to us for direction, and to repair decimated sectors of our economy.
