But if 2020 is the year of corona, 2021 must be the year of Europe, the year of optimism, and the year of real solidarity. This is particularly true in the area of migration. People are still dying on our shores. The same Member States are still responsible for a disproportionate number of people. We need to give humans at least the same importance that we in this House give to our fish, our seas and our crops.  The new migration pact must finally make us a Union of shared responsibility. Our approach must be permanent and not ad hoc. The bottom line must be every Member State showing meaningful solidarity in a system that is fair with those in need of protection, firm with those who are not eligible and harsh with traffickers. The challenge for our generation is something that we can only tackle together.   – Marbuta ma’ dan kollu, hemm ukoll il-ħtieġa li nagħtu protezzjoni lill-media indipendenti. Irridu li b’mod ikkoordinat niġġieldu wkoll is-SLAPP. Dmirna hu li nsaħħu lill-ġurnalisti u l-media kontra dawk li jridu jdgħajfuhom. U rridu wkoll insaħħu l-ġlieda kontra l-korruzzjoni. U nieqaf hawnhekk: il-korruzzjoni hija l-kuntrarju ta’ dak kollu li l-Unjoni Ewropea tirrappreżenta. Jekk mhux se niġġieldu l-korruzzjoni, jekk dawk li huma involuti fil-korruzzjoni mhumiex se jitressqu l-qorti, allura nkunu qed nissograw li titnaqqas il-fiduċja fil-proġett Ewropew.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. This is not the first time that the Union is facing a major crisis, but for the first time it is so widespread and has such powerful consequences. In the face of a pandemic, steps such as jointly combating COVID and a joint recovery plan are appropriate actions. But during the pandemic, we have also seen in a more glaring way than usual all the weaknesses of the Union, which are mostly due to shallow integration and the predominance of intergovernmental over Community mode, and yet community mode serves Europe better. The majority vote is more functional than the unanimity in the European Council resembling the Polish liberum veto, which contributed greatly to the fall of the Polish state in the 18th century. A clear turn towards citizens, not governments, is needed. Deeper integration, an effective foreign policy, more competences for the EU institutions and improved decision-making are needed. If these objectives require treaty changes, they must be initiated. The debate on the future of Europe will be a good opportunity to do so.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Mr President! Dear Ursula von der Leyen, dear colleagues. Thanks for a good speech. The European Union faces incredibly complex challenges, many more than when we began cooperation last year. We're really going to climb steep mountains together, and that's going to take a lot out of all of us. Some need to get better at working together. Others need to spend more time on individual cases, while others should again dare to be more ambitious, especially on behalf of the climate. But we must all remember that we have only been given the opportunity to sit in this room because the electorate trusts us and trust that together we can make Europe a better place to live and a stronger role model for the rest of the world. We must not betray that trust. Whether it is a question of lowering CO2 to the maximum or raising the gavel the moment the rule of law is violated, then we must behave properly towards each other, towards the task and constantly with the will to deliver results. So thank you for giving more headwinds to a 2030 climate target well above 55%, but too bad you did not describe a proactive and effective fine fund that better fits the inviolable principles of the rule of law in the EU. I look forward to a good working year

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work and for the COVID has indeed changed a lot in the last year. But it has also pointed to the problems of the European Union, which have intensified, like a burning glass. Social divisions are growing: hundreds, thousands, millions of people on our continent have lost their jobs and are unemployed. The tax burden on workers is increasing, while the tax burden of large corporations continues to be very low due to tax trickery and tax havens, and profits, on the other hand, are rising massively. The rule of law is ignored. It is the governments of Hungary and Poland that are destroying European fundamental rights and gradually destroying them in their country. We must take action against this. Migration shows that we are not creating a common approach. It is a disgrace to Moria that individual governments continue to block here in Europe. We need to change that. I believe that these are the issues that we need to change next year, we have to do together.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare today's first voting time open. The votes will be open from 1.00 pm to 2.15 pm.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the continuation of the debate on the statement by the President of the Commission on the state of the Union (2020/2696(RSP)).

name: Riho TERRAS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work Mr President, thank you for your meaningful speech. I am pleased that the European Union is serious about our backlog in the area of research and development and the application of new technologies. Investing EUR 8 billion in quantum computing is a very right and timely step. It is also positive that many other developments related to the digital revolution create a better living and working environment for our people and increase their opportunities. The establishment of a functioning digital infrastructure in rural and remote areas is a much-needed activity.  There are no simple and linear solutions to the challenges we face today. The health crisis caused by the COVID-19 virus is one of the best examples. However, in addition to the virus that affects our daily lives, the security environment that surrounds us is also of extreme concern. In your speech, you did not touch on the issues relating to the european Union's readiness for defence. In my opinion, we cannot be satisfied with the fact that nothing can be done about russia's established pattern of behaviour. Stopping the construction of the Nord Stream-2 gas pipeline would perhaps be a clear signal to the Russian leadership that there is a limit somewhere. Unfortunately, the European Union has not yet shown that we have a common and clear understanding of the security threats that threaten us. A clear example is a significant cut in defence spending in the next financial framework. In your opinion, what are the steps that would adequately meet these challenges?

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, let me thank you explicitly for your speech today at the State of the Union. Firstly, because it effectively addressed the major challenges facing Europe, in fact, the world, but above all because you have outlined a future project. A future and a project that is hopeful, and that is what Europeans need today.  In your project I see a common thread and that is that man is again central. For example, by ensuring that all Europeans are entitled to a decent wage, and that means a project on a minimum income in Europe. For example, by re-emphasising the importance of our colleague Timmermans' mission in the European Green Deal, in which people are once again central. Because saving the climate doesn't mean saving the earth. The earth will save itself. No. That means saving humanity.  And speaking of humanity - and I found this very strong and I would like to emphasise this very strongly, and for that you have the support of our entire group - humanity has no sustainable future if human rights are not at the heart of it. And your firm commitment to hatred in Europe, to anti-Semitism, to women's rights, to all those rights of the LGTBQ community. You have really given me a heart, and I honestly think that is a hopeful future project, which makes me proud of our European values and that makes me particularly proud of being European today.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, President von der Leyen, while the pandemic is evolving by injuring our citizens and changing our lives, the social market economy offers a safety net. And that is the achievement of our Europe, and we thank you very much for that from our hearts. But the European Union, as a global player, is called upon to make three brave decisions, starting, in my opinion, with a realistic redefinition of our relationship with Turkey. Is there a Member of the European Parliament here who believes that Turkey's accession perspective is alive? Turkey is in violation of international law. Turkey is violating the arms embargo on Libya. Turkey is violating the rule of law. Turkey is turning world heritage sites into mosques. Turkey threatens the sovereign rights of two Member States. It is time to lead Turkey, as the European Union, to comply with the rule of law. It is time to lead Turkey, as the European Union, to comply with international law. The second brave decision is real solidarity for the refugee. You will indeed bring the new package. But this new package must include mandatory sharing of responsibilities, as there are countries that bear the fruits of the European Union, are controlled for the application of the rule of law, and at the same time do not apply any of the rules of solidarity. As Europeans we need rules — solidarity rules — and we need to implement them. And the third decision concerns our strategic autonomy. It is necessary for the new era to go hand in hand with tackling climate change, digitisation, but also the possibility of leaving no one on the sidelines. Let us give our citizens the security, opportunities, protection and life we deserve.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear President, Respected President of the Commission, the European Union has long been no more an experiment than a political fact, unique in history. However, the European Union is at a turning point today.  In the first weeks of the pandemic, many asked whether the European Union would emerge from this crisis, changed or not even come out. In a short time, the coronavirus has jeopardised the European Union's heritage built over the past decades.  With your State of the Union address, you offered reasons for new European optimism as an upgrade of the agreement reached this summer and the high expectations of citizens who are very much feeling the effects of unprecedented economic woes in recent times.  Let's take advantage of the crisis, deliver on the green deal, continue the digitisation process, start the Health Union, invest more in science and research, relying on a strong cohesion policy. For example, the islands have proven by energy transition that small changes can have a big impact. Our recovery and growth must be sustainable and the disbursement of European funds based on the rule of law. By strengthening the common foreign and security policy through qualified decision-making and restoring enlargement policies, we are ensuring a stronger Union in an increasingly chaotic international environment.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, thank you very much to Mrs von der Leyen for the enthusiasm and motivation she has given us. In fact, this is not just a debate on the state of the Union. This is a debate on the survival of the Union.  Europeans and the world need a strong and resilient European Union. You have realised that concrete measures are needed, direct messages that touch on the problems that each of our fellow citizens are experiencing at the moment, quick responses with a sense of solidarity to the immediate challenges posed by the pandemic.  We need to launch a new cycle of hope. Respond, recover, transform. Respond by putting into practice the solidarity instruments we already have, but we have to put them into practice. Recover, adapting institutional processes and having own resources. And transform with all the strategies we know, in digital, energy, in the multilateral affirmation of the European Union. It's a challenge we have to be up to.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The European Union may never have faced as much of a challenge as it does now. But these extraordinary times have brought extraordinary deeds out of Europe. It was here that the largest EU bailout of all time was born, protecting European jobs and European citizens. However, there is a prime minister in Europe, a Viktor Orban, who is threatening to veto this package simply because it includes the conditions of the rule of law. The reason is simple, they do not want the rule of law condition because they also want to steal this EU money in Hungary. I ask my fellow Members to ask themselves: Are the decent European citizens you represent working to make Viktor Orban the richest man in Hungary with their money? Whose regime invaded Hungary's largest internet newspaper, seized and eliminated Club Radio, and now the last time Hungary cultural warrior attacked his old university, the University of Dramatic Arts, and now I was only talking about the last few weeks of the Orban regime. Because if that is not what the European citizens you represent are working for, then I ask you to stick to the rule of law, tooth and nail, because this will not only protect Europe, but also protect millions of decent Hungarian people against their own trealula government.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President of the Commission, two points, the first on the United Kingdom and the message is simple, we want a good agreement for a future relationship that serves the interests of both parties, but the European Union cannot make the second agreement with those who say that it will not comply with the first. It's as simple as that.  In order for a new agreement with the United Kingdom, as we wish, Boris Johnson's government must ensure full respect for the exit agreement it has signed and that it is a clear obligation under international law.  The second message is this: the European Union faces many challenges, but none is more decisive than meeting citizens' concerns in responding to this devastating economic crisis caused by the pandemic. The Council's proposal can and must be improved in the negotiations with Parliament, but everyone must remember the essentials: money must reach the economy, and reach the real economy quickly. European citizens would not understand any more delays and failing to respond to the crisis is to fail at all and it is to jeopardise the European project.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable members, listening to today's debate, we are seeing where the state of our union is, and this is the sign of a very strong democracy. It shows all the ideas, all the projects and all the demands. It also reveals a lot about this period of uncertainty and change we are in.  I listened carefully to your demands, to your fears, to your anxieties and questions, because your voices are the voices of the European people that you represent. So thank you very much for this enormously inspiring debate over many hours. I heard what you said on the urgent need to come forward with a European solution to Europe's challenge on migration, and I think I heard the message – like my message – that we need to step up. All of us. As I said, next Wednesday the Commission will come forward with a new pact on migration. At the heart of it is a commitment to a more European system. I can announce that we will abolish the Dublin Regulation and we will replace it with the new European migration governance system. It will have common structures on asylum and return and it will have a new strong solidarity mechanism.  I'm very looking forward to the debate. Let's discuss this. There will be points where we agree and there will be points where we disagree. I heard very interesting proposals that we should take into account. I know that I'm partly preaching in the wrong church when I say that, at the very end, the most important part is that we come to a result, but I know that the German Presidency, at our side, also wants a result on the topic migration. So I'm looking forward to the next days and weeks, when we're going to discuss that subject. On the subject of climate protection – I have heard the Chinese proverb very well, and I quote my colleague: 'Demand a lot from yourself, expect little from the others'.  When I take the first part, I can fully sign it: "Demand a lot of yourself". It is right that we must show that it is possible to operate successfully without over-exploitation of our planet.  I am counting on the strength of our engineers, our small and medium-sized enterprises, which have often been rightly mentioned today and who can show that innovation and climate protection can go hand in hand. Mr Pieper was right to ask that small and medium-sized enterprises be given their space in these discussions. We are fully aware that it is only possible for small and medium-sized enterprises. It will not be a matter of small and medium-sized enterprises, only small and medium-sized enterprises. But conversely, we also know that small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of our economy, and that small and medium-sized enterprises are characterised by this ability to innovate in the many, many fields, in niches, which will then lead us to be the world market leader in these niches. So use these innovations, use niches, move forward, that is the sign of our small and medium-sized enterprises, and that is what we are counting on here too in the progress we need.  We can show that the circular economy works. We can show that production without greenhouse gas emissions is possible. Today, the term 'hydrogen' has often been rightly used, the lighthouse projects that we will launch together. When it comes to the second part of the proverb 'Expect little from the others', I no longer agree with it. We have to expect a great deal from the others, which means that I do not deny that a maximum of 10% of greenhouse gas emissions are from us Europeans. But the other way around, it becomes a shoe. If we take the carbon border adjustment mechanism, the carbon border adjustment mechanism: I would prefer it not to be introduced, namely that other countries that export to us – that is, we import here – that other countries set up their ETS system, their emissions trading system so well that they would like to put the price on CO2, that other countries are keeping this money at home. , and we do not have to use a carbon border adjustment mechanism to put the barrier that we do not have a carbon leakage.  Other countries must also lead the way, but we currently have the technological leadership in Europe, and I am counting on that, because I firmly believe that humanity will do everything possible to stop this deadly climate change. We know what will happen if we don't stop it – it was rightly said, "The planet doesn't mind in the end, but humanity on the planet?" If we want to stop this climate change, it will be about these new technologies. Then I want Europe to be at the forefront, for Europe to export these technologies to the world, for Europe to be able to show that it works, and for us to be the exporter. China is now introducing an emissions trading system, they have and that's good – experience gained with it, that's the step in the right direction.  If we show that we can have a successful internal market, a successful European social market economy, with simultaneous climate protection, with the transformation through the European Green Deal and the digital, then we are on the right track. On the subject of NextGenerationEU, the comment came from Sweden: why should the Swedes actually do this, support NextGenerationEU? "Why give money?" was about the sentence. Well, I just want to answer that I met with CEOs from Sweden. One CEO from a very well—known car company explained to me that his car company is actually very important in Sweden. It's a car company that is giving its share to the prosperity of the country and is creating good and qualified jobs.  But he told me that his company cannot build a single truck in Sweden on its own because it needs spare parts from other EU Member States and it needs supply chains all over Europe. So it is in the common interest of Sweden and the European Union that we bounce back to prosperity and restore the supply chains. This is going to pay back Sweden a thousand fold, and is the right investment to make. So this should be the answer we give to the question that was raised. Throughout history, wars and pandemics have changed the course of the world. That is certainly true for our continent and it will certainly be true for this pandemic. In front of us is the opportunity of a lifetime to shape that change. The change will happen, but let's shape that change and not be shaped by it. But we can only do that if we do this together. What I heard today was – not in all cases but in the vast majority of cases – most encouraging. I invite all of you to embark on this historic journey together. You listened to me – for quite a while, I know – and I listened to you. I think we have a plan, we have the investment and I think this will now be the year of implementation, implementation, implementation. For me this is the most important part now. Many times have I heard: 'yes, the concept is right, yes, they are good ideas, yes, you have a roadmap, yes you have the investment, now implement, deliver, deliver, deliver'. Our duty is to design our destiny and I want to go on this journey together with you. (Applause)

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Madam President of the Commission that credibility is essential if you want to implement reforms or your ambitious agenda, and it is also essential if you want to speak in a single voice in international affairs and show an alternative to democratic opposition in Belarus or elsewhere.  Implementing the rule of law criteria is an issue on which the Commission is not credible. I just want to remind you that the MFF proposal which was brokered by the Commission and the Council was rejected by this Chamber exactly on that ground and for that reason. We have so many times heard your words on no compromise on rule of law that we all know it by heart and we are somewhat bored of it. I’m also happy to hear that the Commission is going to compile a report on rule of law and I will be very happy to read it and I will be very glad to come back here and debate it. But I’m afraid that it will have absolutely nothing new to say to me on my country at least, Hungary, where my country stands on rule of law. The criteria that you have set out – judicial independence, press freedom, institutional checks and balances, corruption – I can tell you exactly where Hungary stands on this subject and on this issue and you can save your time and energy.  This week I was very happy to come here and listen to the Commission Vice-President Věra Jourová stand up for linking EU funds to rule of law, saying who doesn’t understand the talk about values will understand the language of money. After this I was curious to come here and hear some details and specifics from you about what this will really entail, but now I’m a bit suspicious that once again the money talks, will work backwards and in another way.  Last time we discussed here in this Chamber rule of law in Hungary and heard from the Commission that there will be no compromise, a few days later a German Minister, your successor to the Ministry of Defence in Germany, Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer arrived in Budapest to sign one of the greatest contracts on arms deals in the history of Hungary with the Hungarian Government. Is there anyone surprised here why there is little if any progress on this issue vis-à-vis Hungary. Ms von der Leyen, when will you back up your words with action on rule of law?

name: Manon AUBRY
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, after almost three hours of debate, I have the impression that we have been witnessing a dialogue of the deaf, to be honest. We talked to you about social justice, equality, climate, the fight against tax evasion, you have answered us competitiveness, stability, single market, fiscal sustainability, here are your words. But what troubles me the most is your lack of honesty. First of all because, at no point in your speech, do you tell us how the stimulus package will be funded. Are you planning to play Euromillions or do you think you have a real plan for own resources at European level? A tax on financial transactions, taxation of the biggest fortunes or ecological dumping is the only way to prevent European citizens from paying for the crisis. Second, NGOs are already alerting you, but you are fiddling with the numbers. Your target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030 is actually only a 49% target, since you are changing the methodology by including carbon sinks such as forests. If you prefer to compare pears to bananas now- or any other expression - if you continue to make up the accounts, then no one will believe you. Speaking of accountability, of course, you have to be accountable to the citizens rather than, precisely, make them up.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking You have talked a lot about solidarity, about protecting the dignity of jobs. It is very good that you have seen and discussed these topics. You have also talked about equal opportunities for development, but at the same time you are raising the idea of increasing, accelerating co2 reduction by 2030, which excludes entire regions and many, many Europeans from the chance to have such a decent job. Climate change must be combated. It is necessary. But you have to do it rationally.  The second point that I want to address and which, I hope, will also be taken into account by the Commission, or at least you will bend over, and I ask the President to look at this first and foremost, is that fake news does not become the basis for the fight against the rule of law in individual countries, because that is what happened, among other things, in the case of Polish who is accused of violating the rights of individuals. that promote LGBT ideology.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, President von der Leyen, you said it yourself, now is the time for implementation. Now we had the announcement of which we share many of them, but of course the important task is to put all of that into life, and I want to thank you for your strong words when it comes to human rights, be it on the human rights of refugees, of LGBTI people, also human rights in Russia and in China. The question is, what are the consequences of those words? How will we put them into action, into life, what action will follow? I think it’s very important to make sure that our policies are coherent so that we’re not exporting weapons and then are surprised about refugees, that were not subsidising fossil fuels and then wondering about climate change, and that we also don’t put profits over human rights when it comes to our external relations – and I’m thinking about relations with China, where there’s lots of important talks going on, but also, for example, when it comes to Russia. Thank you very much and good luck. We’re ready to support you.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Madam President of the Commission, Mr President of Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Mrs von der Leyen, you gave us a very pathetic State of the Union address here today. There is no doubt that this titulation of your speech is done with care. In the end, however, it is just another shameless label fraud by the Commission. The bond is clear: it is a transfer of the speeches to the State of the Union as we know it from the President of the United States, or the State of the Nation speeches, as European Leaders sometimes make. There is only one crucial catch to be taken by this choice of words: the United States of America is a state, Germany, France and Italy are states. But the European Union is not a state, and you, Mrs von der Leyen, are not A Head of State, and if you would like to be one. You can still make so many long state of the Union speeches.  And I assure you that we will fight your far too advanced request to develop the EU into a separate state, including its own exploitation rights of citizens, by granting taxation powers and, more recently, debt powers. Please remember, the EU is not a state, and we will work, with everything in our capabilities, to ensure that it never becomes one. If, in the usual hypocrisy of this House and the Commission, you therefore tell us that we are opponents of Europe or that we are even enemies of Europe, then I would like to say to you: we are not the real enemies of Europe here, no, you are! For the ideals on which our wonderful and diverse continent is historically and culturally based are the ideals of freedom and democracy. You trample both of these things underfoot here through your superstate fantasies with the appropriate power over the citizens of Europe.  You are currently using the Corona crisis, which is indeed a crisis, but by no means such an unprecedented disaster as you would like us to tell us, specifically to the presumption of ever more competences at EU level, where they are in no way justified. COVID-19 is really very convenient for you. You are talking about an unprecedented counter-attack in an unprecedented crisis. They find in it the welcome opportunity for ever more communitarization.  You are talking about a recovery fund – a recovery fund – as if we were at the end of a disastrous war with devastated cities and millions of deaths to be mourned, as was the case in 1945. That is nonsense! It is a deliberate, deliberate oversubscription of this crisis, which we actually have through COVID-19 and, by the way, also through completely excessive lockdowns of economic life. Your so-called counter-taxes through debt and taxation, Madam President of the Commission, will not help us out of the crisis. On the contrary, I say to you that it will exacerbate the crisis, because it leads us on a completely wrong, socialist path. It is no coincidence that the Greens and the Communists applaud you the most in this House.  I ask: How historically blind can you actually be? The lessons of the 20th century, which is terrible to a large extent and for hundreds of millions of people, are still not understood. You are on a disastrous wrong path, the price will be enormous, not for you personally, but for the citizens whose interests you claim to represent here.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: – Mr President, President von der Leyen, today you undertook a lot of commitments, which is the right way to do things, but I think now the expectation of people is to start to deliver. After one year of mandate, after more than six months of this crisis, I think now, a lot of people are waiting for us to deliver results, to come with the legislative proposals.  First of all, in order to give credibility to all this project and to all this amount of money committed on behalf of Europeans, I think we have to insist on two main things, and you mentioned this in your intervention today. First of all, to clearly connect money with values, resources with values. This is an important pillar for a real European Union and second to reinforce new own resources. This is the only way to build a real European project.  We expect very clear results in this direction. I hope that the Commission will be on behalf of Parliament in order to fight for that. So if the first step in order to rebuild our European credibility was to come with a plan, with a vision, this is done, in my opinion. Now the second step is to start to deliver and to implement these results and we have to work together on it, because I heard here about people who don’t hear or don’t see really what’s happened. I think only those who don’t want to, didn’t perceive the fact that we have really made progress.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: – Mr President, I believe that today we have done a good exercise, here, of listening; to listen to the differences, which obviously exist, but also to listen to everything that unies us —which is a lot — and we have been able to hear regrets, but we have also heard proposals. By the way, Mrs. Von der Leyen. If I were you, I would be very proud to hear the criticisms of the far right you have received during this plenary session, because they show very much your commitment to building more and better Europe.  I have one very clear thing: Europe will be social and just or it will not be. Europe will be green and sustainable or it will not be. Europe will be feminist or not. Because all these are the values that un bring us together as a project: equality, justice, tolerance, solidarity... And those are also the values that will make the survival of the European project possible. Let's make this moment of crisis also an opportunity. And let us be able to understand that it is time to be close to the most vulnerable and to call for an effort - of course also - for those who have the most to sustain the European social model, in order to advance the fight against climate change, in order to address the European social pillar. This is our task at the moment and we must be aware that there are, today, many people having a great time, with fears, with uncertainties, with anxieties, and who have only one thing, the hope that Europe will respond to their problems. Therefore, it is our responsibility, but above all, our obligation.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Mr President, Madam President, at every debate I hear from colleagues that they are not anti-European, but that the only Europe that would work would be a sum of states with minimal cooperation. This Europe, ladies and gentlemen, we had it at the beginning of the health crisis: the Europe of everyone for themselves, of everyone at home, of withdrawal and minimal cooperation. I do not think the record has been very satisfactory. However, we must be clear-headed, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen: the failure of this Europe of withdrawal has not, as if by magic, restored confidence in the integrated Europe that you are proposing to us. But today, I join you, there is a historic opportunity for Europe to prove that it can be an ambition and a solution for the future, not a utopia of the past. You had a proactive speech, which I salute. You had a speech with many ambitions, many of which meet those of our group. Our role from now on will be to implement this very ambitious roadmap. Be careful, the task will not be simple. Our citizens expect concrete, visible, rapid action that addresses their concerns, not just good intentions. We will therefore have to ensure first of all budgets that will enable us to achieve these ambitions in terms of solidarity and strategic autonomy. Let me express some doubts about the current forecasts, which are very much dependent on the Member States. I am thinking in particular of defence, which unfortunately has not been much discussed today. I am also thinking of agriculture, which has not been much discussed other than by the Green Pact for Europe, but which is the basis of our food autonomy and this is something we must not sacrifice. Madam President, we will have to work today on the rapid implementation of this roadmap and we will have to make sure that the budgets follow and, I must conclude on this, that we will not make a policy out of touch with reality. Indeed, we are in an institutional bubble, including us Members of Parliament, which is sometimes far removed from the concerns of our fellow citizens. We must ensure that people are brought closer to these institutions.

In July, the foundations of the recovery were laid and it must now be the Member States that carry out the reforms, which must be aimed at strengthening public health, fair digital and ecological transition, social and territorial cohesion and gender equality.  As Socialists, we have an impact on the need for a European Poverty Strategy that includes the Child Guarantee, a Minimum Wage Framework Directive and a Decision on Own Resources and European Taxation to prevent the burden of tax collection from falling on the income of workers.  We are alarmed by the deterioration of the rule of law in some Member States, where judicial independence and the protection of human rights are endangered. That is why we have asked the Council to take an immediate formal decision to negotiate a European Rule of Law Mechanism.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – Somewhat surprisingly, this speech was a particularly sympathetic part of foreign policy for me. It would be difficult to add anything to the President of the Commission or to correct his attitude anywhere. He spoke as if he were an Estonian, a Latvian or a Lithuanian. Our values and sense of danger were clearly expressed by Ursula von der Leyen. If you were to, however, the attitude towards the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline would have been to expect more. For now, he essentially said that more is needed to change Russia, that one pipeline will not change Russia. Whether or not he will support the construction of the pipeline to the end remains unknown. Of course, I was looking forward to the digital approach with particular interest, and a strong message came out of this area – Ursula von der Leyen stressed the need to create a single digital identity for the European Union. Yes, we have a mechanism for the cross-border recognition of digital identities in the Member States, but unfortunately its use has not reached the masses and there is not much to do with the digital identity of Estonians elsewhere in Europe. I hope that the very strong statement of the President of the European Commission will be followed by concrete actions.  The President's approach to the data economy and artificial intelligence was no different from that of the previous Commission. Curiously, the President did not mention a single digital initiative announced by this Commission, the Digital Services Act.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Writing. – Last Wednesday, Ursula von der Leyen (VDL) delivered her first visionary State of the Union address to the Eu Parliament. Von der Leyen already sees herself as President of the Republic, but the EU is not a state. She wants to change that. And how does VDL want to help the spirit out of the bottle? By giving up even more of national sovereignty, more spending, more climate policy and, of course, more migration. Corona made it clear that the EU needed a common health and social policy. The EU must also tighten up its climate protection policy and reduce its CO2 emissions by 55% by 2030 rather than by 40%. It is not mentioned that the EU contributes less than 10% to global CO2 emissions. The EU also wants to protect the rule of law. This means: measures of Poland and Hungary, as well as moralizing devaluation of the powers of China and Russia. And finally, a commitment to migration. Migration has always existed in Europe, it has defined us and shaped our culture. Migration enriches us. Not a word, however, about the cultural and financial costs. In addition, the EU will take even tougher action against so-called hate speech in the future. The EU will develop VDL into an "anti-racism union". Ursula VdL's speech reads like the visionary moral sermon of a late-called high priestess. Those who have such visions should better go to the doctor.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: In writing. Madam President of the European Commission, you sometimes say beautiful things. When you hear you talk, you almost want to believe it. But unfortunately, between the lines, the reality is less beautiful.  I take two examples. First, the workers. Those who have run our society throughout the crisis. Those who today have to fight not to bear the brunt of the crisis. What concrete perspective do you give them? What guarantee of employment? What is the salary guarantee? You're talking about wage dumping. Very well. But you offer no concrete way to end social dumping. No, your first priority is the market and the market again. And soon, the return to austerity.  A second example. In April, you promised us that the Covid-19 vaccine would be "our universal common good." So you promised us that the vaccine would not be privately owned by a large multinational pharmaceutical company. Today, while you are in the middle of negotiations with multinationals, you are not repeating it. Do you no longer dare? Or did you lie to us in April?

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – Ursula von der Leyen's speech began with a tribute to the workers who were in the front lines of the fight against the virus (Covid-19). I, too, join the tribute and warn that support for Labour must not end in symbolic gestures.  In her speech, the President highlighted a series of welcome priorities that are supposed to contribute to the consolidation of the Union, but (intentionally) without a clear sequence or plan. I particularly welcome the Commission's unequivocal commitment to building a health union, taking on a greater initiative in responding to crises by strengthening the EU civil protection mechanism, securing jobs and setting a European legal framework for minimum wage and collective bargaining. As part of my field of work, I will also actively seek to ensure that the Commission implements as soon as possible the commitments to strengthen the EU's competence in ensuring the social security, health and well-being of EU citizens.  The crisis in the event of the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic once again demonstrated the inability of states to act quickly and in a coordinated manner. Some prime ministers and countries are trying to compromise to reduce the much-needed funds for the recovery from the pandemic, as well as funds for a green (fair) transition. Thus, with the exception of a few months when people have been given an advantage over the interests of the economy, the Union is unfortunately still all too focused on pursuit of sustainable (economic) growth rather than sustainability.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Written. There is no doubt that wages need to be raised across Europe. Being able to live on your salary is a foundation on which we have built our society. We can never accept a social order in which work does not provide financial security. It is gratifying that Mrs von der Leyen says she wants to improve the conditions for Europe's employees. Something needs to be done about low wages across Europe, but the solution proposed by the Commission in the form of European minimum wages is not the answer. The introduction of binding legislation in the field of pay is outside the competence of the EU and goes against the EU Treaty. It is also contrary to the premises that prevailed when Sweden joined the EU, when the Swedish labour market model would remain closed. The Swedish labour market model, which means that independent parties set wages through collective agreements, has over the years yielded good returns for both employees and employers in Sweden. In Sweden, we should not have political interference in wage formation. We Swedish Social Democrats want to actively contribute to work in the EU to strengthen the social partners and to build functioning collective agreements systems in more countries. We can also support recommendations to countries with minimum wage schemes. On the other hand, binding legislation on wages is not compatible with our labour market model.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – The communications of the President of the European Commission were very clear and unambiguous at today's presentation of the situation in the European Union. The crippling world left behind by the Covida-19 pandemic must be back on its feet as soon as possible. We therefore need decisive action from Europe.  Von der Leyen promises europeans protection, stability and opportunities. He's got all my support in this. I welcome the construction of a health union, one of Europe's most important political projects since the pandemic. The virus cannot be stopped at the border. It is high time that we confer more powers on the Union in the field of health policy. I support the President's initiative to strengthen key EU agencies and to create a new one for biomedicine, research and development.  I am also pleased to announce a binding mechanism for establishing a minimum European wage and the European Commission's commitment to a 55% reduction in emissions by 2030, even if I wanted an even more ambitious plan. We need to further transform, digitise and re-eradicate economies and Europe so that we are truly ready for the future. At the same time, we must protect the EU's strategic interest and common core values. I therefore particularly welcome von der Leyen's initiative to extend the European Penal Code to ban hatred and any form of discrimination and to protect the most vulnerable.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Written. – For me, Commission President Von der Leyen is absolutely setting the right priorities: social, sustainable and innovative. Work must pay, making a European framework for minimum wages a must. Together with a strong network of temporary unemployment, we are building a genuine social Union. The strong emphasis on collective bargaining is crucial. The ambitious but achievable climate targets, with the necessary resources for strategic investment, must also be focused on the Member States. We must work on a strong European health union. This will enable us to act more firmly in the next crisis. The reconsideration of the distribution of powers in the field of health care will no doubt also be on the table in the discussions on the future of Europe. I also welcome the new European Agency for Biomedical Research and the enhanced role for the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and the European Medicines Agency. A first important task for the European Union is the development and roll-out of a vaccine. By working together on a safe vaccine that is accessible to everyone, we can save lives. Now we must all turn this ambitious State of the Union into action!

text: in writing. – The COVID-19 pandemic has been charged, still charged, a very high toll in Europe. The most dramatic, that of the thousands of citizens killed by the virus. name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – In her first state of the EU address, EC President Ursula von der Leyen sought to meet the demands of all relevant political factions, including our social democratic one. In fact, it announced not only the creation of new jobs, but also the strengthening of the protection of the most vulnerable populations and the negotiations on raising the minimum wage. I was particularly pleased that, at the time of the corona crisis, it stressed the need for a financial strengthening of the European Health Union, which would certainly be helpful for countries such as Slovakia. These will also depend on external assistance for testing, medical supplies and supplies of medicines in the event of an expected outbreak of a more severe second wave of COVID-19. As a compromise between the pressures of the European Parliament and the resistance of some Member States, I consider the announcement of an intention to increase the percentage by which, in order to achieve carbon neutrality, greenhouse gas emissions are to be reduced from the current 40 to at least 55% by 2030. Achieving this will be very difficult for some states and industrial sectors, but we already have instruments such as the Just Transition Fund at our disposal. I will do all the more to push for an increase in funding for this fund, both after the cuts by European leaders and my colleagues in July.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. We are pleased that the Commission sees more in Europe than just a single market. Social measures such as Minimum Wages in Europe and a climate-neutral Europe where everyone can participate are sorely needed. The European Commission shows that it has understood this. At the same time, von der Leyen ignores essential points such as the rule of law and migration. As far as we are concerned, she should have put more emphasis on the refugee crisis and, in particular, the disaster in the Moria refugee camp. We therefore expect clear plans from the Commission to help these people in need. Von der Leyen also addressed the LGBTI community, but the Commission must go beyond just giving them a heart. Money can no longer go to European regions that flore our values. That's never in question with us.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: In writing. Since the Lisbon Treaty, the President of the European Commission's State of the Union address has been increasingly a reminder of a moment of self-competition during which the representative of the executive branch, now Mrs von der Leyen, takes stock of the actions of the College of Commissioners while presenting the outlines for the future. Well, this year, marked by the COVID-19 crisis, the President of the Commission should avoid praise and self-absolution and acknowledge her total incompetence, demonstrated during the management of the pandemic, in the field of public health and for the economic crisis that resulted. With regard to the health crisis, the Commission was conspicuous by its absence, given that under Article 168 of the FUE Treaty, it was supposed to complement national public health policies and coordinate supplies of medicines and medical devices. With regard to the economic crisis, Europe's Hamiltonian moment, the creation of a federal debt, with a loan of 750 billion euros on the capital market, marks the beginning of a hellish spiral of public debt by an organization that had made balanced budgets its trademark.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The European Commission has raised the bar of its decarbonisation ambitions to 55% by 2030. The question is how we will achieve this target and what the economic and social costs will be. I believe that we will only be able to succeed through coordination. That is why I have tabled a number of amendments to the Regulation on Recovery and Resilience, calling for the drafting of projects that bring European added value. Some examples would be the development of projects on the movement of eu inland waterways (on the Danube, in the case of Romania) or the installation of automatic systems by rail. We have also proposed the development of projects in tourism and aeronautics. A European decision will be needed to oblige Member States to invest out of the EUR 750 billion available in these European projects. If only one state invests on the Danube and the others do not, then the desired result is not achieved. This is why coordination is needed at European level and then at national level. As the President of the European Commission, Mrs von der Leyen, pointed out, things would move much faster if decisions were taken in the Council not by unanimity, but by a qualified majority. The success of achieving the Union's green objectives could also depend on this change, which seems increasingly necessary.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: in writing. – The State of the Union debate in Parliament dignifies the EU. For the solemnity. For the moment of reflection. For the opportunity to question the President of the Commission about the course of the last year and about the future. And this year is well loaded with challenges: the traditional and all those who are the result of the crisis.  The President rightly highlights the EU's geostrategic role. It considers this a geopolitical Commission. The EU is at the heart of the network of multilateral alliances. It is a pillar of the multilateral system. It privileges relations with international organizations. It recently approved a strategy for Africa on five pillars: growth and jobs, Green Deal, digital transition, peace and security and migration and mobility. Good neighbourly relations, peacekeeping and economic growth in the EU's neighbouring regions are also a priority. The same is true of humanitarian aid and development policies where the EU is the world's most generous funding partner. I choose this theme because the EU budget proposal 2021/2027 is clearly insufficient to meet all these ambitions. The Commission's proposal to increase eu foreign policy funding by the Recovery Fund did not have the agreement of the European Council. In fact, the crisis has had an impact on international organisations, the multilateral system, citizens and third-country organisations.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: in writing. – These are challenging times for the European Union. The degree of complexity of today's challenges has greatly increased. With our eyes set on the future of citizens, we must do everything possible to build a genuine European Health Union that is more resilient to future threats. We have a duty to give an unprecedented economic response. The financial incentive must reach European people and economies quickly. Only with concrete measures that promote sustainable recovery and growth will we be able to overcome this crisis. It is therefore absolutely necessary to protect the weakest by strengthening social support and a commitment to creating a minimum wage throughout the European Union. Ensure financial support for the digital transition and strengthen the commitment to decarbonisation of the European economy by 2050 at the latest. Finally, there is an urgent need to address the demographic challenge we face. We will continue to make efforts to emerge from this pandemic stronger and with a robust and more coordinated European strategy. The goal? This remains the same: building a more united, more supportive, stronger and more democratic Europe.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – During Commission President Ursula von der Leyen’s State of the European Union speech, I was pleased to see ambitious and concrete actions regarding digital and technology policy. More concretely, in three main areas: Increasing our industrial data cloud capacities so we can obtain the benefits of innovation and economic growth; a human-cantered approach to Artificial Intelligence and a new law for EU digital identity; investing in broadband infrastructure and connectivity. I welcome all of these commitments on the side of the Commission, as I am a firm believer that we will not be able to achieve any of our ambitious sustainable economy goals without technology. We must work towards identifying the investment streams to cater for future breakthrough technologies to help transform existing industries, e.g. steel and cement, automotive, aviation, and more. We must also strive to identify the ecosystem of start-ups and small SMEs that can come up with the future clean breakthrough technology solutions and can create European technology leadership. If the European Union is to meet our ambitious green goals, maintain our global position and ensure a high living standard for our citizens, we must continue to be at the forefront of technological advancements.

name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: in writing. – Madam President Von der Leyen, I begin by welcoming the European Commission's sustained efforts to achieve climate neutrality in 2050, as well as today's proposal to increase the 2030 greenhouse gas emission reduction target from 40% approved by Parliament and the Council in the previous legislature to at least 55%. The effects of climate change, however, have long been taking effect in most Member States, where thousands of hectares of fertile land are transforming into deserts from year to year. We therefore need, and I call on you in this way, an ambitious European action plan with clear objectives and regular evaluations, as well as the allocation of adequate European funding to prevent and remedy desertification and land degradation in the European Union.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – I welcome the first State of the Union speech by the President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen. From a balanced and constructive approach to results, however, the distance is long. In order to move forward, the European project must evolve, add new skills in the field of health and education. The European Parliament has high expectations about the future of Europe and it is time for the European executive to fulfil the promises made. Four important points were present in the speech: - supporting my initiative on the creation of the European Emergency Medical Corps based on the positive example offered by Romanian doctors; - the introduction of the European minimum wage actively supported by the Romanian left and the petition signed by more than 20,000 people; - references to the decency of work, including for seasonal workers; - the need for a balanced digital transformation that focuses on innovation, accessibility and infrastructure. In order to develop, the EU needs to take on ambitious projects on digitalisation, education and training, as well as on environmental protection. However, for any initiative, we must ensure that these transformations leave no one behind, and especially that we are united in our internal and external action. Europe must provide solutions for sustainable and equitable development at European level.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – In her first State of the Union speech to the European Parliament, Ms von der Leyen faced the problem of having her declaration of vision and purpose dominated by the coronavirus pandemic. She could hardly ignore it, and sought to find the right balance between firefighting and articulating a long—term mission. To a certain extent, the Commission President achieved this. Her proposals to bolster the public health component of the EU’s profile were constructive and down to earth. On the other hand, there was little new where the main horizons of EU policy (especially the Green Deal) are concerned, though affirming them again as she intelligently did makes sense. However, the commitment expressed to make QMV operational in more areas of EU activity actually underlines a basic aspect of the state of the Union today that she failed to address: the locus of decision—making within the institutions has shifted again towards the Council. Both the Commission and the Parliament make bold proposals, then go into wait—and—see mode while Member States palaver about the issues. Regarding this, the President did not seem to have anything better than a band—aid solution, when what is needed is an institutional revamp that addresses adequately the political and social realities.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: in writing. – The Speech of the President of the Commission left a set of very good intentions. It was important to hear the right and humanist views on European policy on migrants and refugees. I hope that they will be shaped by the European Pact for Migration. There was a clear criticism of human rights violations at the Union's borders and a commitment to the establishment of a relocation procedure based on binding solidarity between Member States. The disaster of Mória is its very existence, as well as of many other refugee camps, where hope goes out in the inhumaneness of survival. I also take as very positive my defence of the end of the mandatory rule of unanimity in the EU on decisions on human rights and foreign policy, something i have always been fighting for. I hope there is enough political courage to move forward.  Let us see if the vision that the President of the Commission revealed in her speech will be effective, overcoming selfishness, nationalism, populism, in short, the short views of many. Unfortunately, we have become accustomed to seeing great ideas and proposals take too long to get out of the paper and, when they leave, they often fall short of the ambition indicated in the presentation speeches. I hope this time it might be different!

name: Christine SCHNEIDER
text: Writing. I support the position of our President of the Commission. Corona pandemic, climate change, digitalisation or migration – Only together will we stand up to the current crises and challenges and make Europe fit for the future. It is right to see the European reconstruction fund NextGenerationEU now as an opportunity. Raising the CO2 reduction target to at least 55% by 2030 is very ambitious. Now we need to see how this objective is to be implemented. For me, technology neutrality plays a big role in this. Moreover, we must not overburden our small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: in writing. – Dear Madam President, you have talked a lot about the economy and health, about migrants, the Green Deal. I didn't hear anything about culture or education. It's like they don't exist for you. 7.4 million Europeans have been left out of work in the cultural sector, mainly "freelancers". They do not have a permanent job or health insurance, do not receive unemployment benefits. You talked for over an hour and didn't mention them once. Is this the bright future you promise the young? A world of illiterate, easy-to-manipulate voters? During quarantine, tens of millions of citizens imprisoned at home sought refuge in the culture. They watched movies, theater, ballet and opera, visited virtual museums. The cultural sector continued to work to maintain their spirit. It is impossible to fully assess the contribution of culture to the preservation of mental health during quarantine. You set a price – 0! There's time to come to your senses. Set off special funds to restore the cultural sector. My colleagues and I have submitted a motion for a resolution requiring at least 2% of the recovery budget to be allocated to culture and to increase funds for Creative Europe. Give 2% compared to 30% for green policies. Otherwise, when you achieve climate neutrality, your citizens will be spiritless half-human, looking squirrels in trees. Thank you.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – The State of the Union address by The President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, indicates many positive initiatives by the European Commission in its future working direction. From the themes of the European Green Deal, to the EU's readiness for the digital age, to strengthening democracy and the EU's stronger position in the world. Her speech was directed to a large extent at the top representatives of the Member States, without citing the financial rules for fiscal policies. From this, it can be assumed that, in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, the emphasis on the economic level will be more focused on raising revenue for national budgets than on limiting spending and not indebtedthing of individual Member States.

name: Mihai TUDOSE
text: in writing. – I appreciate the ambition expressed by the President of the European Commission in the European Parliament plenary. His first State of the Union speech is politically successful and offers an encouraging perspective to citizens traumatized by the pandemic and the social-economic crisis. With one condition, however: that these good intentions translate into swift action, as expected. On behalf of the European Parliament, during this critical period, there was prompt cooperation in adopting the first measures to support the Member States. Unfortunately, the largely common vision of Parliament and the Commission is being spended by a Council paralyzed by the rule of unanimous decision and by the selfish interests of some of the oldest states of the Union. European citizens need concrete support to cope with the hardships they face. I call on the Commission to act so that support from Brussels reaches where it is most needed. The health emergency is matched by a social-economic emergency. This is the correct order of priorities. Then we can make plans with the 2050 horizon. But it is appropriate that these plans, such as the energy transition, be economically and socially sustainable so that they can be implemented.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – The annual meeting of the current President of the European Commission was held for the first time at a time when the EU was also in serious crisis. Since then, Commissions have come and gone, national governments have changed, but one thing has become almost permanent: the crisis. This is not necessarily a bad thing, because crises encourage people to constantly develop and improve, so our European community can only get better. As a Hungarian MEMBER, in this debate, I could talk about the community-destroying policies of anti-EU, illiberal governments and damn the leaders of the Union for watching helplessly for years as political adventurers who trample on the rule of law turn them into fools. As a Hungarian MEMBER and one of the drafters of the Concept of the European Health Union, I now want to highlight the importance of health in the debate on the future of the Union. Health, which has been a third-rate area for the EU as a member state's competence. However, the coronavirus has shown that without health systems that can provide strong and quality care, there is no health, but there is no economy that can be operated predictably. This is a life-changing time when radical transformations are being made: the imbalance between member states' health systems cannot be maintained any longer. We need a solution that leaves the competence of the Member States, which is over-feared by many, but guarantees quality care and patient safety everywhere. This is the concept of the European Health Union. I think it is a major breakthrough that the President of the Commission has joined the cause.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. "The past year has been demanding for the whole of Europe, and the coming autumn will not look any easier. For the future of Europe, we have four major challenges to solve this autumn. The key is to boost sustainable economic growth and competitiveness. After the acute coronavirus crisis, Europe faces a major economic challenge. Just as Ursula von der Leyen outlined, in order to boost growth, it is important to dismantle red tape for businesses and barriers to the internal market, to strengthen capital markets and to invest in the Green Deal and digitalisation. At the same time, the most important foundation of the European Union must be ensured: common values. Democracy, freedom and the rule of law must be ensured in all EU Member States. We must also be able to find a common line on immigration policy. We can't afford to fail again. The fourth essential theme is the common foreign and security policy. The Union is too slow and sluggish here, as seen in recent events in Russia and Belarus. In international crises, faster responsiveness is needed. Foreign policy decision-making must therefore be changed and made more effective by increasing qualified majority voting. This year was supposed to be a big year for the European Union in climate policy. Although the coronavirus crisis has taken up a lot of time and energy, the European Union must remain committed to being climate neutral in 2050. I support the Commission's proposal to tighten the 2030 emission reduction target to at least 55% to ensure this.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. My personal conclusion, following The speech by President Ursula von der Leyen here in plenary on the State of the Union, is that the situation is serious. Although the President of the Commission has had many words of praise for the EU, the problems of our Union cannot be denied, whether within it or at its external borders. While the clear commitments expressed in the speech to an anti-racist Union, equal rights for LGBTI people and a human rights-centred foreign policy have given hope, the half-hearted lip service to the much-needed asylum reform, and the equally urgent conditionality for disbursement of EU funds, have not been able to convince that these words will actually be followed by deeds with their hands. There were clear words in the pleas about strengthening borders, improving repatriations and combating smugglers, while I sorely missed them in terms of human rights protection for refugees or the rule of law. In the end, President von der Leyen's speech was like the state of the Union itself: full of light and shadow. Full of opportunities that will allow us to have a better, more social and more united Union in the future if we seize it. But also full of problems which, if we do not approach them courageously and in a European spirit, will bring our Union to a test.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. The most appropriate term for describing the state of the European Union is 'stagnation'. Our continent has been overwhelmed by one of the greatest crises in history, yet Brussels continues to pursue its political line, showing a total lack of self-criticism. The opposition forces are accused of extremism, which is therefore ignored and excluded from any decision. We are witnessing daily appeals to defend the rule of law and to democracy, but when a political leader and former minister is sent to trial for defending his country, Italy, no one moves a finger.  On the geopolitical front, the EU shows inconsistency and inertia towards China and Turkey, certain that it can count on the weaknesses of a system based on the particular interests of some Member States: a myopic and unsuccessful approach, which primarily harms European citizens.  The EU should think carefully about what has happened in recent months, bearing in mind that The Member States will only really be able to start again after the suspension of certain rules imposed by Brussels. There is no more time to lose: unless there is real change, Europe will continue towards a decadent drift that will come to an end.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: I give the floor to Mr. Androulakis, who requested an opportunity to speak under Article 59(4), return to the Committee a report on the amendment of Decision 1313/2013/EU on the EU Civil Protection Mechanism for interinstitutional negotiations COM(2020)0220 - C9-0160/2020 - (2019/0097(COD).

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for the confidence you have shown us in voting in favour of the amendments we have tabled in plenary. Parliament, just three months after the presentation of the European Commission's proposal, is ready to start negotiations. In accordance with Rule 59(4) of our Rules of Procedure, I call for the dossier to be returned to the Committee on the Environment so that we can start negotiations with the Council and the Commission. I hope that the German Presidency will soon understand that there is no choice but to come to the negotiating table without delay on such an important issue for the European Union.

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to follow suit with my colleague and I would like request a referral back to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety for entering into interinstitutional negotiations. I’m very glad that the amendments have been carried. I hope that the final vote will carry too, as this is a very important topic if we look at the CO2 emissions from maritime transport.

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, today, President von der Leyen called for European buildings to become less wasteful, less expensive and more sustainable. As rapporteur for this report, maximising the energy efficiency of the European building stock, I know we can do this. I want to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their close cooperation and support during negotiations. We now have a strong and united position on our demands for the upcoming renovation wave strategy. This is a good news story – we can create jobs, tackle energy poverty, improve air quality and reduce emissions in these extraordinary times. It tackles the health crisis, the economic crisis and the climate crisis. Yesterday, weather records were broken here in Belgium. 35° of heat is not normal and we know that 40% of emissions that cause this come from buildings. With the right investment, buildings can reduce emissions rather than raise them.  The report says we must fight energy poverty by working with neighbourhoods and communities to ensure healthy and safe living conditions and ensure affordability. We must raise national targets and revise the energy efficiency directives and the energy performance of buildings directives and binding minimum energy performance standards are required. We also require integrated renovation programmes, a holistic approach from rooftop solar and e-mobility, from heat pumps to district heating is required. So let’s use recovery funds for the renovation way.  I endorse the President’s call for a new Bauhaus. As an architect, I welcome this. So let’s harness the creativity, the design skills and the demand for change and let’s start with the worst performing buildings and the communities most at risk. Let’s lift people out of energy poverty and give them the buildings and the homes that they deserve.

name: Nathalie COLIN-OESTERLÉ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to first of all greet my fellow rapporteurs who have accompanied me in this work. The text we will be voting on today and tomorrow reflects our common desire to provide concrete answers not only to patients, families, but also to health professionals who are affected by these drug shortages. This crisis has highlighted our growing dependence on third countries, mainly China and India, and the concentration of supply in the hands of a few suppliers. We discover, barely late, that public health has become a geostrategic weapon capable of bringing a continent and beyond to its knees. If health is the responsibility of each member state, it is up to the European Union to coordinate and complement these national actions. I welcome the announcements made this morning by President Ursula von der Leyen, who wants to build a true Europe of health. I call on the Commission and the Member States to accept our proposals in this direction. They are based on three pillars: more cooperation, coordination and harmonisation. In particular, we propose the creation of a European emergency pharmacy and a common basket of priority medicines and vaccines, the extension of the competences of the European Medicines Agency to make it the regulatory authority guaranteeing greater transparency in the distribution chain, but also at the level of The Member States' stocks, the repatriation to Europe, where possible, of all production lines , through tax and financial incentives, and finally the creation of one or more European non-profit pharmaceutical establishments, capable of producing medicines that are often essential, but which are neglected by manufacturers, for lack of profitability.  At the same time, of course, we must make Europe the drug continent of the future, investing heavily in research and innovation and diversifying our resources. In the European Parliament, we have taken on our responsibilities: we have worked together to provide answers. I now call on the Member States to do the same and to act collectively. Arnaud Danjean said, individual actions are quite counterproductive and we have seen it. We need a real European pharmaceutical industrial strategy to regain our health independence and ensure patient safety.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I remember when I was six years old and i came to school. I was called "dirty gypsy" by the children and beaten. On the school bus my friend was not allowed to leave me a place because the other children called him a "gypsy friend". I can hardly describe to you how these words and this way of dealing with me hurt. Forty-seven years later, so many children with a Romani background must feel the same pain as I did. I am here today and it is a great honour for me to speak for my people in this House on this special day. At the heart of European democracy, a strong call for equality, justice and inclusion is being heard. This House and its honourable Members, you, ladies and gentlemen, are do justice to the largest and most oppressed minority in our European history. We will work together to defend ourselves against inequalities and injustices and will strongly affirm that equality must apply to all people, regardless of ethnicity. Ladies and gentlemen, it is now in your hands for each and every one of you to take an important step against centuries-old injustice and to allow justice for almost 80% of people with Aromance i-men who live in precarious life situations in the EU. With this historic resolution, we are launching a process of giving these people a perspective for improvement and an opportunity for real equal participation. The shadow rapporteurs and I have worked with the people of Romani background scare to finally make their voices heard. It is precisely the voice of the people with a Romani background that you hear in this report. We have managed to do it together – thanks for the good cooperation to the shadow rapporteurs! – to put on the table a crucial report in which we demand nothing more and nothing less than equality for people from Romani backgrounds.  Ladies and gentlemen, you can change the lives of many people in a positive way today, you can be part of this historic process today. Yes, you can do it, do it! They have the power to create justice.  (The speaker concluded his speech in a language which is not the official language)
